text:
Fabulous!  I hadn't had Snickerdoodle cookies since I made then in home-ec in high school over 20 years ago and they were just as wonderful as I remembered them to be!  I was careful not to overmix the batter and then I chilled the batter before scooping into balls and I bought fresh baking soda and cream of tarter to ensure that they wouldn't flatten out.  The cookies were puffy, slightly crisp on the outside and tender in the inside.  Delicious!  Family loved them...they were so easy...can't wait to make them again!

text:
These cookies are PHENOMENAL! They taste great as is but I think with a little alteration you could come up with a great variety of different flavors. Omit cinnamon in the sugar, put lemon extract in instead of vanilla and you've got a yummy, chewy lemon cookie! Add almond extract instead of vanilla and put a piece of chocolate on top (omitting cinnamon sugar coating) and there's a lovely cookie dying to be eaten. I can't wait to experiment with this recipe!

country:
None
text:
I tried this recipe once as given, because I don't believe in modifying until you've tried the original.  The original is slightly bland and, if you roll the dough into balls, a bit time consuming and tended to be a bit crisp on the bottom due to the cinnamon-sugar mixture.  The second time around I did as other reviewers suggested and omitted the shortening.  I also did the cookies drop style and sprinkled the tops liberally with the cinna-sugar.  My boyfriend ate the first dozen before they were even cool.  Seriously, don't bother with the shortening and the ball rolling.  You will have an easy, dynamite cookie that you can't bake fast enough for your family!

text:
This was the first time I have ever made snickerdoodles, too.  I made a few alterations to the dough to ensure that the cookies would be moist and chewy - a lot of times snickerdoodles can be crispy.  I used 1 cup of butter and omitted the shortening.  I melted it and then added the sugar.  I subsituted 1/2 cup of white sugar for brown sugar and 1 cup of AP Flour for bread flour.  They turned out just like I wanted - nice and chewy with just a little crisp on the outside.  Will make again!

None
text:
This recipe is an all-time favorite of mine - I frequently use it to entertain friends. It can be easily doubled or halved.

The one thing to be aware of is that, because they spread out very much, they must be placed VERY far apart, and also they are very sensitive to overcooking. To get that perfect, still-light-on-the-bottom taste, I check them every minute beginning about 2 minutes beforehand.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/275168.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made the dough for Beth's other cookie recipes and frozen it to give as Christmas gifts for the last 3 years. Last year I added this Snickerdoodles to the list. It was a huge hit! I use a cookie scoop and drop into a bowl of Cinnamon & Sugar mix. Then place on a baking sheet and freeze 1-2 hours. Then put frozen dough in freezer zip bags. You can bake any flavor, mix and match right out of the freezer. Just place on a baking sheet lined with parchment paper, bake for 13 minutes at 375 degrees. I found you really need to sift the flour then measure. Especially when making multiple batches. I was asked at Thanksgiving by several family members "your still making cookie dough for Christmas right!?!?!" Thanks Beth

text:
These are great! Really easy and straightforward. I didn't have any cream of tartar so I used twice the amount in fresh squeezed lemon juice. Turned out perfectly. Following some of the other reviewers tips on baking them for only 8  minutes, I found that they needed about 2-3 minutes more then that. They were way to gooey in the centre and LOOKED under down. I also couldn't get them off the cookie sheet without them squishing and changing shape. So 10 minutes is perfect. I also let them sit on the cookie sheet for a minute or two in order to release.

text:
This is the best snickerdoodle cookie recipe I've made!!!  Not to crispy on the outside and soft inside.  My neighbor came over and wanted to know what I was baking.  I gave her a cookie to try and well, let's just say she took a plate full home!  measure the ingredients as listed and you shouldn't have any problem getting a great cookie. I did chill my dough for 30 minutes before rolling.  Note** it's important to remove cookies to a cooling rack when they come out of the oven and not let them set on the cookie sheet.  They will continue to brown. Happy baking!!!

text:
Even though the recipe said it made 4 dozen cookies, I was only able to make 3 dozen from the recipe. Maybe my cookies were a little on the larger side, I am not sure. Besides that fact, these cookies were wonderful. I followed others advice and only baked them for 8 minutes and I also used a ziplock bag to cover the cookies with sugar and cinnamon. I also followed the advice of using 3 T sugar and 3 tsp cinnamon, and that helped to ensure the cookies were coated well. I brought these cookies over for a get together, and they were all gone within 30 minutes, and there were only 7 people! I will be making these again soon. Thanks for this great recipe.

text:
Take these out of the oven while they are still soft and very light colored - the cinnamon on the bottom makes them prone to a burnt taste. Also, store them with a piece of bread to absorb the air - they lose their chewiness quickly otherwise!

These cookies were very good. They took exactly 8 minutes to bake, and my oven usually runs on the cool side! As recommended by a previous reviewer, if you don't want crispy bottoms to the cookies, just dip the tops in the sugar and cinnamon. Also, the dough is easier to work with if you chill it a bit before rolling into balls.

text:
We're always enjoyed this recipe for snickerdoodles. If baked properly, they always turn out chewy on the inside and crispy on the outside. I always roll the whole ball in cinnamon and sugar, but often have to mix more by the end. I like the cinnamon and sugar taste! I also always use lard for these instead of shortening (no trans fat or hydrogonated oils, and some think better taste...since you get satuarated fat either way). Definitely enjoy making this recipe when I need a crowd-pleaser.

text:
This is an excellent snickerdoodle recipe.  The cookies came out chewy on the inside and crunchy on the outside as promised, but I was careful and baked them for only 7 min. because snickerdoodles have the tendency to become hard after cooling if they are baked too long.  I only made one change and added 1/4 tsp of cinnamon to the cookie dough.  Another recipe to add to your box!

text:
These cookies are really good. However, I did make some changes based on other reviews. I used 3 Tbsp sugar and 3 tsp of cinnamon powder for the topping. Also, I think it all depends on people's oven, I baked the first batch for 8 min and took it out right away, but it came too "set", crispy, and not chewy. So, on the later batches, I baked it only for 7 min and it came out perfect. Chewy, just the way hubby and I like it.

text:
This is the exact recipe I have been using to make my snickerdoodles for the past 40 years.  It was passed down from my mother and Lord knows how long she had it.  You can not go wrong with these cookies and they are always in demand around here.  In fact, my hubby's nickname for me has been "Snickerdoodle" for the past 25 years.  The only thing I do different is use one cup of margarine instead of any shortening and cook for exactly 8 minutes.  You do not want to over bake these to get the full cinnasurgary goodness.  A classic cookie if ever there was one!!!

Display Name:
bamacook
isPro:

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674154.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
PLEASE NOTE:  Normally, I would give this recipe 5 stars, since it is identical to my grandmother's recipe, which I have made before and love!!

However, everyone out there needs to know what NOT to do, which is what I  tried today...Splenda Blend for Baking.  Normally, I have very good results with it in other recipes, but this was a notable exception.  The flavor is no different, but the texture is VERY different.  The cookies did not spread out baking in the oven, turning into laughable hard brown biscuit-shaped cookies.  And they are very dry and crumbly inside.  On the last batch, I tried doing the peanut-butter-cookie-trick of criss-cross pressing them with a fork.  This is the only way that these turn out acceptable -- at least they have the correct shape and color, but still are dry inside.

So, in summary, Ms. Sigworth has a great recipe here, but wanted others out there who are considering Splenda Blend in these cookies to know my experience.

5

Beautiful cookies! I had never eaten or made Snickerdoodles before so i wasn't sure what to expect. I love them (I'm having trouble leaving them alone as a matter of fact). city:

country:
None
text:
Thanks Mrs. Sigg for your wonderful recipe.  Here are some of my notes and advice I followed...
· Changed ingredients: used all butter, 1.5 tsp vanilla, .5 tsp almond extr., 3 C. flour, pinch salt.
· Refridgerated dough for a little while.
· Rolled 3/4" balls.  Shake inside bag of cinn/sugar mix – 2T/2t. mix is just barely enough.
· Placed them 7x5 on cookie sheet.  Flattened w/ cup
· Baked at 375* F for 7min. Nicely Crackled, puffed, but flattened out.  Made 150 x 2” cookies
· Froze some pre-rolled ones. Baked 6min at 400*F + 7min at 350*F - little too long, came out really crunchy, but stayed puffed w/o flattening - not very crackled, but still yummy! - will try to perfect this baking time, but such a good idea for rainy days when you only need a few fresh cookies :) Thanks for all the good tips everyone!

Very good snickerdoodles.  Do not overcook them.  They definitely don't look done at 10 minutes, but any longer and they lose their softenss.  Even if they don't appear cooked, pull them out at 9 minutes for a nice soft cookie.

text:
Do I really need to say these cookies are fabulous with all of these other reviews here?  I did the 3tsp/3T cin/sugar in a baggie per someone's suggestion on the site and it worked great.  I've made these numerous times and they are ALWAYS a hit.  I even messed up and put too much flour in one time and they were still great, just a little poofier, slightly less chewy in the middle.  Now I do it on purpose occassionally just to change it up once in a while.  I do tend to be paranoid about overcooking them so I think I might've pulled them out too soon a couple of times.  They have become my signature cookie because they are so easy to make in a crunch.

My family are snickerdoodle experts.  I try every recipe I can get my hands on and enjoy the slight variation of each one.  This is a great traditional recipe.  Snickerdoodles must be crunchy on the outside and soft on the inside - and these are.  Using a small cookie scoop I made about 40 cookies and they took more like 10 minutes per sheet to bake.  Use a silpat baking mat for extra protection.

Loved these cookies.  Baked at 375° for 8-9 mins.  Used parchment paper, and cookies slid right off. text:
I had never heard of snickerdoodles before I came across this recipe, so I wasn't sure of how they were supposed to turn out.  But they were VERY yummy.  I used an ice cream scoop to drop them onto the trays, and then sprinkled them with the sugar/cinnamon mixture (which kind of was concentrated in the middle of the cookie and sparser on the outside edges as it spread but oh well).  I also (whispers guiltily) melted the shortening and butter instead of softening and creaming it, but it worked out fine.  I'd definately recommend this recipe to others.

text:
I was called to make snacks for my daughters pre-school class at the last minute (a couple of hours).  I didn't have a whole lot on hand to prepare anything, so I turned to All Recipes.com and found this wonderful recipe.  My daughters (3 & 5) even helped.  I only had egg substitute but they still turned out great.  Instead of rolling into balls and dropping in the cinnamon mixture, I dropped by teaspoons onto the cookie sheet and sprinkled the cinnamon/sugar mixture on top.  They won raves from everyone.  The kids loved them and the teachers even asked for the recipe!  I agree on the 375 degree oven for 8-10 minutes.  My husband agreed these were the best cookies ever.  Thanks for sharing the great recipe!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Wow, definitely some of the best snickerdoodle cookies out there. BUT there are some "musts" that you need to keep in mind:

Make more of the cinnamon and sugar than it calls for-- I doubled the recipe (including the cinnamon & sugar) and it was not enough. I recommend making 2X the amount it calls for. Keep in mind that I made my cookies a bit smaller. 

Cream the butter and sugar together ALONE before you mix the rest of the wet ingredients in if you are mixing by hand. It will create clumps of butter that are such a pain to get out otherwise. 

Also, be careful of overmixing the dry ingredients in the wet; do the least stirring as possible-- it's probably just easier to mix by hand. 

I cooked my cookies for 8:30min and it made the bottoms crispy and the insides soft. 8 minutes for me seemed like it was too moist on the outside (but it really is personal preference). 

For some reason, my later batches turned out flatter than the first ones. I don't know why, it could just be my oven, but just be aware that it is a bit difficult to get these cookies exactly uniform in size.

text:
So I literally just pulled my first batch out of the oven and here are my thoughts and observations:  They turned out great! 

First things first.... I didn’t have on hand and didn’t want to spend money on shortening or cream of tartar so I doubled the butter and took the advice of other reviewers and mixed the baking soda with lemon juice and that worked great! It worked out better for me to roll the cookies in the sugar and cinnamon mixture on a flat plate rather than in a bag. I found that my bake needed to the full 10 minutes (maybe because of the altitude where I live?).  The most important advice I can give you is....  unless you are extremely talented or a baking gymnast, I don’t recommend trying to move the entire sheet of cookies from the baking sheet to the cooling  rack in one swift move.  Trust me when I tell you it’s easier to move them one delicious ‘doodle at a time. 

These cookies turned out crispy on the outside and chewy on the inside and so yummy.  I’m not talented baker but this recipe is easy and a new favorite.

Made recipe exactly as described. I take them out at 8 min exactly. They will seem too soft, but by the next morning thet will have cooled and set into perfection. If you are eating them immediately you might do 9 min, but to take in to work or for events, make them the night before and take out as soon as possible. They will be perfectly soft and melt in your mouth with that soft tang from the cream of tartar.

text:
Excellent recipe.  Follow the directions as written and you can't go wrong.

For those of you reading previous reviews for this recipe, please do NOT test for freshness of baking soda by placing in water and looking for the fizz.  Baking soda requires acid to fizz so test by mixing with diluted vinegar.   Using water alone only works with baking powder (it is a mixture of baking soda and acid).

text:
Hands down the BEST Snickerdoodle recipe ever! I’ve been making these EXACTLY as the recipe states. I do usually make a bit more cinnamon sugar mixture than the recipe calls for- I always seem to run out half way through. This recipe makes about 3.5 dozen, 2.5 inch diameter (cooked) cookies. Cook them for exactly 8 minutes, keep on cookie sheet for 1-2 minutes after, as they are pretty soft (and will continue to bake). If you do that, you will have perfect, golden brown bottoms and slightly crisp edges and soft, chewy centers. Perfection!!

text:
This is the BEST snickerdoodle recipe and the only one I ever use. My brother in law loves them and they are always eaten right up! But DO NOT over cook them! They will become hard and far too crumbly. I keep an eye on them and sometimes do a test sheet of cookies for the first round. You want them to be lightly (emphasis on lightly) brown. Sometimes when I take them out they still look a little raw, but worry not, they stiffen as they cool and make for one delicious and chewy cookie!

Display Name:

city:

country:
None
text:
I have made these cookies three times now following the recipe to a T.  The first time I made the cookies, I was really disappointed.  I was making the cookies for a coworker's birthday and The cookies turned out super flat.  I like my snickerdoodles to be thick and soft on the inside, so I was pretty bummed.  I opted to leave the cookies home and pick up a fruit tray from the store.  

My second experience was also for a coworker's birthday.  I felt like I needed to try the recipe again.  Once more, I followed the recipe to the letter, and my first dozen came out perfect.  My second dozen were flat again.  Confused, I realized the only difference between the two batches was the cookie sheet they were cooked on.  I placed the third dozen on the first cookie sheet and viola! Perfect cookies.

Now on my third time cooking these, I have switched all my cookie sheets to match the other and all my cookies are perfect.

The moral of the story, the cookie sheet may affect how your cookies turn out.  In my case, the aluminum cookie sheets I had used in the past created flat cookies, but the non-stick sheets (Wilson brand....not sure that matters) work wonderfully.

All in all, the cookies have great flavor and I will definitely make them again.

Love these cookies!  So soft!  The only thing I did different was substitute two things. I replaced baking with baking powder instead of baking soda and cream of tartar. I also used double butter because I had no shortening. They were still so puffy and delicious!

As a baker, I love to try new recipes from allrecipes especially with high rating. After following the recipe exactly, I found that the flavors definitely had potential, but there was too much cream of tartar that you can taste and the cookie itself was far too crunchy. I like my cookies soft and unfortunately this recipe as is didn't deliver. My mom, however,  will love this recipe since she prefers a biscotti-like crunch. But as for me, I wont be making this recipe again.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The snickerdoodle recipe to end all snickerdoodle recipes. Seriously, this is perfect. My main complaint about most snickerdoodles is they lack the "tang" they're supposed to have (otherwise, it's not a "snickerdoodle" to me). If you don't like the tang, you might want to drop the cream of tartar by a quarter to a half. But that's not a snickerdoodle to me. Perfectly soft insides, crispy outside, light and airy, with a tangy aftertaste. I bake cookies once a year--for Christmas--and this is the only cookie I bake. I can't get cookies like this anywhere. As for timing, ovens are going to vary. For me, at 400, 11 minutes works exactly right. Experiment with a few batches to see where it's how you like them with your oven.

text:
My family loves these cookies. They are soft and chewy. I took them out at 8 minutes and they were just barely under done so I put them back for 1 minute longer and that was perfect. I substituted margarine for the 1/2 c. shortening because I did not have any and I only had a 1/2 c. butter left. I also substituted the cream of tartar and baking soda with baking powder because I had no cream of tartar. I was worried those modifications would ruin the cookies but they came out absolutely fabulous. Best cookies I have made so far. Simple and delicious.

Very easy cookie to make. The only change I made was 4 tsp. of baking powder. I have made other cookie recipes with baking soda and cream of tartar and didn't like the taste. Also tried varying the oven temp between 375 and 400, the cookies had to be closely watched at the higher temp. Other than that I was completely surprised at how easy the cookies were to bake. Unfortunately I has to make another batch of cookies. Couldn't keep from eating them!!!!!!! Thanks for the versatile recipe. Next time I am going to try lemon extract with lemon zest.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2559950.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Just made these - used all butter, did let the dough chill for about 30 minutes prior to rolling into balls.  I put the cinnamon/sugar into a small bowl and just rolled the dough ball around until it was coated - worked great.  Once the cookies bake and spread (and they will spread!) the coating will not be so dense, so don't worry if it seems heavy-handed.  I used my Silpat baking mats, let the cookies bake for 10 min until set (but not wet looking in the center) then brought them out and let the cookies sit for about 5 minutes on the baking sheets.  They came right off the Silpats without sticking (once they had cooled a bit) and I put them on cooling racks.  For a few cookies I substituted Pumpkin Pie spice for the cinnamon - haven't tried them yet but couldn't resist a fall twist on these yummy cookies.  Oh and I was careful not to overmix once I added the dry ingredients.  My cookies puffed up nicely.

I've been baking this recipe for about 10 years now. It's the only snickerdoodle recipe I've used since I've found it. If you want PERFECT snickerdoodles, this is the recipe to go with. I've also tried it with it just rolled in sugar because I didn't realize I was out of cinnamon one day and they were devoured. They make perfect sugar cookies as well :)

text:
I added 1t salt (since it seemed short) & 1/8t baking powder (for a little omph!).  These were fine.  'Didn't like this recipe any more or any less than other snickerdoodle recipes.  It made 3 dozen - using a cookie scoop - exactly the right amount of cinnamon-sugar.  The cinnamon-sugar itself was a little - well, cinnamony :/  Yeah, yeah, it was supposed to be.  'Think instead of 1 part cinnamon to 3 parts sugar, an increase of 4 parts sugar might be better.  It's just a little strong of not-sweetened-enough cinnamon with the first bite.  'Got a thumbs-up from E,17; 'Don't want more than one from K,15.

text:
first time making snickerdoodles and these turned out perfect! definitely change the 2 tsp white sugar and 2 tsp cinnamon to 3 tsp sugar and 3 tsp cinnamon. I did what one reviewer wrote and put the cinnamon sugar in a baggie and dropped the balls of dough in, gave it a good shake, and had it perfectly coated. Also, my dough was initially very crumbly - but about 1/4 cup of water helped A LOT. my sister, who isn't really a fan of cinnamon, couldn't stop stealing them off my plate. :)

text:
Very good cookie. However, the dough was very soft and sticky.  I added about 1/2 cup more flour and chilled the dough for about 20 minutes.  I also added quite a bit more sugar to the cinnamon/sugar rolling mixture.  I baked the cookies at 400 degrees for 10 minutes, and removed them from the pans immediately.  I used shiny insulated baking sheets covered with parchment paper and had no trouble with burning.  Beware any kind of dark cookie sheet! The resulting cookie was just as described, tenderly crunchy on the outside and soft on the inside.  I'll be making these again!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674157.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Helpful Tip:Theses are really good cookies and a good recipe. But, just like with Cut-out cookies, the dough once you have put all the ingredients together, needs to be refrigerated for at least three hours. If you do not refrigerate first before baking them, they will be extremely greay and sticky when you are forming them into balls to then roll in the cinnamon-sugar mixture.Tip:they will still be sticky and gooey. when you are forming them into the balls rolling them in the palm of your hand however, does that just from your normal body temperature. After you have all of the balls on the cookie sheet, slightly wet the bottom of a rounded glass, and slightly press the balls down. Note:you do not want to completely flatten the balls, just slightly flatten. This allows the cookies to bake more evenly. Enjoy!

text:
This is the second time I've made these and this time they were perfect! I didn't add the SALT because I had salted butter. The first time I made them I added the salt and they were too salty. After I put the balls of dough on the cookie sheet I smashed them to about a little over half an inch thick and a inch apart from each other because I don't like flat cookies and i sprinkled some extra cinnamon/sugar on top then baked for 10 minutes. I took them out of the oven while they were still soft so they would not be too hard later. Everyone LOVES these cookies. Just made 40 and they are almost all gone!

text:
My only problem with this recipe is by rolling the balls of dough in the cinnamon/sugar mixture they were completely coated.  This ended up making the cinnamon way too strong.  I'm surprised that none of the other reviews I've read have mentioned this, makes me wonder if I did something wrong.  Also, be careful not to over bake, remove them before they brown or they turn rock hard.  I'll have to revisit this recipe.

Hands, down, the best! Nice and crispy on the outside, chewy on the inside. As suggested by some other reviewers, I used new baking soda and cream of tartar, and the cookies were nice and fluffy. Also only dipped the tops in the cinnamon/sugar mixture to avoid burnt sugar on the bottom of the cookies. Best snickerdoodles I have ever made.

text:
My friends and family love this recipe!! I normally have to add about 1/4 to 1/2 extra flour to firm up the dough to roll it in the cinnamon and sugar. I also drop the temp to 375* and bake for exactly 8 minutes and removed them immediately from the cookie sheet. It sets the cookie but leaves just a slightly "doughy", chewy center with a crisper outside that everyone LOVES!!

text:
BEST. SNICKERDOODLE. EVAR. Seriously, this was freaking AMAZING! I followed a commenter's tip, and took them out of the oven after 8 minutes and let them rest on the cookie sheet for a minute or two. I also followed another commenter's advice about increasing the cinnamon/sugar powder to 3T sugar and 3tsp. cinnamon. I'm glad I did! because it was barely enough. I'm wondering if the poster ate half the cookie dough before baking the cookies? If so, I can't blame her! The cookie dough is delicious... but the cookies are even better! I wish I could rate this higher than five stars :)

text:
This is an excellent recipe.  Here are the changes I made:

1. I didn't have shortening, so I used butter instead.
2.  I didn't have cream of tartar and my baking soda was old, so I used baking powder instead (which is basically cream of tartar and baking soda combined).  I used total of 3 tsp and it worked well.
3.  I baked the cookies for 9 minutes, as they did not look done after 8 minutes (I'm not sure if that made a difference though)

Overall, this recipe is a keeper.  Very yummy treat!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674157.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
excellent very simple snickerdoodle cookie... a sugar cookie with a little cinnamon twist... I don't know why the other reviewer said it is best to use butter and eggs at room temperature... I tried that and my dough was very sticky and hard to work with... inbetween cookie sheets I popped it in the refrigerator and after 15 minutes it was so much easier to work with.. also I didn't have cream of tartar which can be substituted by using double the amount of lemon juice... I took out the cream of tartar and baking soda completely and used the equivalent amount of baking powder (because it can be substituted by 1 part baking soda to 2 parts cream of tartar) and a splash of lemon juice... mine did not turn out flat at all... the substitution seemed to do the trick... also I think the reason for removing them from the cookie sheet right out of the oven has to do with the ease of taking them off the cookie sheet the longer you wait the more they stick.. but be careful because they are soft fresh from the oven... great easy cookie!!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I liked these a lot.  I tried making Snickerdoodles when I was a kid, but they were a little too tricky.  

To avoid getting those HORRID cream of tartar lumps in the cookies, I subbed 2 tsp of baking powder and 1 tbsp white vinegar.  Skipped the cream of tartar altogether.  They came out REALLY good.  Bake the cookies for just about 8 mins on 350 degrees.  When the cookies settle, they are best with a softer middle.  Thanks so much to all of the people who left notes on here.  I used the tips and was very successful because of fellow reviewers.

text:
This recipe turned out great.  Like others, I had no cream of tartar so I used 2 tsp. of white vinegar instead.  These were easy, they came out light, crispy and chewy in all the right places, and taste great.  

I agree - 8 minutes max.  FYI - my dough was quite light and sticky.  I thought I might need to chill the dough before rolling, but  I baked off a few w/o chilling first and they came out just fine.  So I just used my 1 TBSP scoop to make the balls and keep my fingers relatively clean.

Foodie Mama

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is my first allrecipes review and I have to write in to share what a wonderful recipe this is. My delicious batch of snickerdoodles is disappearing very quickly!  I did make a couple of changes and followed some very helpful tips from some reviewers.  Here are the changes I made: 1) I used whole wheat white flour instead of the all purposae white flour.  The cookies turned out a little darker than using the white flour and they had a denser texture which was outstanding....and just a teeny bit healthier!  2)  I used butter in place of shortening since I don't use shortening.  Be sure to use slightly softened butter. 3) I used 2 teaspoons of fresh lemon juice in place of the cream of tartar 4) I used large eggs, not extra large eggs.  If you have extra large, just eliminate a bit of the white  5)  I mixed the ingredients by hand and did not use a mixer at all  6)  I baked the cookies for 8 minutes only and removed right off the cookie sheet to eliminate cookie flattening.  These cookies are wonderful to dunk in coffee, too!  Bon appetite!!!

text:
After briefly chilling the cookie dough in the refrigerator, I used a small cookie scoop and dropped a few balls at a time into a gallon ziploc bag filled with the cinnamon/sugar and coated the balls gently.  8 minutes was perfect.  Cooled on the pan for a couple of minutes before transferring to a cooling rack.  They are the best snickerdoodles I have ever eaten, and ridiculously amazing while still hot/warm.

text:
I have made these  few times.  While Snickerdoodles aren't my favorite cookie, it's a crowd-pleaser and this recipe IS my favorite for snickerdoodles.  Others don't add vanilla... but this is essential!
One adjustment: Add 2 teaspoons of cinnamon to the egg/sugar/butter mixture if you want the cookie to have more of cinnamon taste.  These normally come out as sugar cookies with a hint of cinnamon (which is also GOOD!)

text:
YUM-MY! These are my husband's favorite cookies, and I have made them several times now. I have yet to justify buying cream of tartar just for this recipe, but have replaced it with equal parts white vinegar with great results. (Although I heard that baking powder is baking soda and cream of tartar, so you can use it instead to replace BOTH ingredients?) Other than that, I have followed this recipe exactly. I pull the cookies out at 8 minutes. They're cooked all the way through, but still have a great doughy taste!

text:
I used almond extract instead of vanilla just because we love it, & oh my goodness - they are spectacular! I will never use another Snickerdoodle recipe, I have now found one that's perfect. 
The dough rolled easily into balls & was not sticky. I was able to remove them immediately from the cookie sheets without having to wait a minute or two. I do use silicone baking sheet liners & these may have made the difference for those of you who had problems with that. 
Such a simple cookie, but absolutely divine. I do suggest you trying these using the almond extract. I promise you will love them.

None
text:
I used margerine instead of shortening and also relplaced the cream of tarter for 2tsp baking powder.  These turned out very soft and yummy!!  I dont roll cookies by hand, I put them in a round tupperware dish and shake the dough around in the sugar.  This way they are covered and rolled at the same time and my hands stay clean.  Also if you want very soft centers take the cookies out of the oven as right after they start to crack.

This is the only snickerdoodle recipe I will use.  I've been making these cookies for years now.  To keep the cookies from becoming too flat, I usually refrigerate the dough for an hour or so before baking.  If I don't have shortening on hand, I use a cup of butter instead.  Love these cookies!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great recipe! Made subtle changes. Substituted cream of tartar with 2 tsps baking powder added 1 package instant vanilla pudding to flour mixture (helps cookie stay soft & moist) and used 1 Cup light brown sugar and 1/2 cup white sugar. Mix wet and dry ingredients separately then add ry ingredients to wet in batches until fully combined. Baked for 9 minutes at 350 degrees. Cookies came out perfect! My son loved them as did my staff!

text:
I used all butter for my cookies and I've never made snickerdoodles before so I'm new to using cream of tartar, but I did notice the bitter aftertaste other people had mentioned, which is why I gave this recipe three stars. Aside from the aftertaste they came out looking nice and my dough was just fine... I had no problems with it being too sticky. I know my oven runs hot, so I baked mine @ 375 and only cooked them for 6-7 minutes so I could make sure they came out chewy since my first batch I left in for 8 minutes and were a bit too crisp for me. I had fun making these but the after taste just kind of ruins the cookie for me.

text:
We love these!!! I live at high altitude so have to make minor adjustments to make baked goods come out right. I add just a bit more flour and reduce the temp a bit. Make sure you pull then out when they flatten and start to crack. If you wait until they turn even a little golden brown, they'll be crispy not chewy. Either way they're delicious!!

userID:
5265474
Display Name:
Lulu
isPro:

followersCount:

4
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/654982.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These were great.  I agree with other reviews that this should be hand mixed.  I have a powerful Bosch mixer, and the cream of tartar and eggs will fluff up to much if you let it run to long.  Perfect texture with and hand stir.  Cream the eggs/sugar/vanilla/shortening/butter, then sift the rest of the ingredients and combine ingredents then Leave It Alone!  Leave the mixture nice and wet, dont give in and add more flour.  Put drops off it onto a plate with plenty of sugar and cinnamon, sprinkle and little on the top of the dollop then you can roll it with your hand without getting sticky.  If you dont overwork it, and you dont add more flour to make it easier to work with, you get the PERFECT texture.  Take it out after 8 minutes and let it finish on the cooling rack. it will seem really soft, but it stiffens right up as it cools.

Really delicious, no-fail cookie, but I make a few tweaks to work for me: I use all butter; I live in a country where there is no cream of tarter, so I use 3 tsp of baking powder. I have made hundreds of cookies over the last few months using this recipe, and it never disappoints. I often will roll them all and dust with cinnamon-sugar and then refrigerate the dough balls and bake off as necessary.

text:
Pretty darn good cookie! I somewhat agree with other reviewers that there is a strong cream of tartar + shortening flavour. Next time, I will use all butter (I rarely bake with shortening anyway) and substitute baking power for the cream of tartar. Also, I ended up with a rather crumbly cookie mix as compared to other types of cookies (like my go-to chocolate chip recipe) but they still turned out as expected: crisp on the outside, soft and fluffy in the middle. I baked them for exactly 8 minutes. Good cookie!

text:
A great recipe 'as is.' It's essential to use all white sugar or the edges don't get crisp, and very important to take the cookies out of the oven and off the baking sheet even if they don't look done. The only thing I was forced to substitute is baking powder for the cream of tartar and baking soda because neither of those ingredients is sold in the country I live. Same great results. My go-to recipe, which is identical to a famous red/white cookbook.

Followed others' advice and increased sugar to 3T + cinnamon to 3.5tsp...also was sure to hand mix the recipe.  Cookies turned out wonderful after baking for exactly 8min and removing immediately from cookie sheet.  I also stuck the rolled dough in the fridge/freezer for a couple minutes before placing in the oven to help keep them from spreading.  Fabulous flavor, easy recipe!

Display Name:
Greg Major

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614259.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great recipe. Personally, I think the real trick is to A) make sure the butter is soft (not melted) and to B) really cream the sugar and wet ingredients. I let mine go until it was nice and light and then folded the dry goods in. The resulting dough was perfectly hydrated and just barely sticky, but very easy to handle. I scooped a healthy tablespoon onto 3/4 sheet pans lined with parchment paper and baked at 400 for 11 minutes (YMMV of course). The result? A wonderful cookie with mildly crispy edges and a nice, soft interior. I do recommend using a good quality cinnamon and, if you can get your hands on it, C&H Baker's Sugar.

text:
every pregnant womans dream cookie right here!!!  I was a little skeptical about the cream of tartar due to other's reviews and the "after taste" but I am here to tell you this is one of the best cookies I have ever had.  I am an excellent cook but a TERRIBLE baker.  I followed others suggestions of hand mixing all the ingredients and they came out perfect!  8 minutes is the ticket, they are crunchy on the outside and perfectly gooey in the middle.  Not sure how old my baking soda was, but I know it wasn't "fresh"... however it didn't seem to make a difference.  I did not have shortening so I used an extra 1/2 cup of butter instead, no problems!

text:
I'm sad that my cookies didn't turn out flat like in the picture...they were very puffy! I am 100% positive that is because I subbed vanilla yogurt for the shortening to save on some of the fat/calories. I also had to use a bit more flour than the recipe called for in order for the dough to be stiff enough to get into a ball and roll in the cinn/sugar mixture. I cooked at 400 for 8 minutes like several other reviewers said to and the bottoms of my cookies were still burnt black so I think next time I will lower the oven temp a little bit. These were really great cookies!

text:
This was phenomenal~  The only thing that differed was I used all butter. Everything else was exact.   I used electric beaters to cream the butter & sugar then hand whisked everything else and only mixed until just mixed as to not over-mix.   I have a wonky oven and only a dark jelly roll pan so I lowered the temp and baked them for 6 minutes or so till golden on the bottoms on parchment. PERFECTION! Turned out light, fluffy, a slight crispness on the outside and moist on the inside.

text:
These were great and the recipe was very forgiving. I don't cook with shortening so I used all butter. I also ran out of white sugar so made them with 1/2 white and 1/2 brown. They were then rolled in cinnamon and brown sugar. I also subbed lemon juice for the cream of tartar and had no issues with them being too flat. I baked them 400 degrees for 9 minutes and removed them asap to a rack to cool. I stored them in a zippered plastic bag and now, 4 days later, they are still as good as they were the first day. Very good cookie!

text:
Wow, what a great recipe!  These cookies are superb.  Followed recipe exactly, except used all butter (1 C.) instead of butter and shortening and baked exactly 9 min in convection oven and removed immediately to a wire rack to cool.  Also, used KitchenAxd to cream butter, sugar, vanilla and eggs (room temp).  Mixed together sep. the flour, cream of tartar, bak. soda and salt and added to wet ingred.  Also used 3 T sugar and 2 1/2 t cinnamon to coat dough balls.  Easy recipe and the kids gobbled em up and mom & I did as well!   Thank you for a great cookie recipe!

text:
Great cookie! I think?  :) lol  I have made this cookie twice and got very different results. The first time the dough was perfect and I rolled and cooked and had a blast. The cookie was flat,not that I minded but I thought that I would try again with new baking soda. The second time I mixed my butter and applesauce in a blender and then mixed everything. The dough was very wet and sticky. The baked cookie was a little cakey for my taste as well.  I was amazed at the difference fresh baking soda can make and also how preblending some ingredients can make the difference between workable and nonworkable dough. Great cookie!! Need new chef! :)

text:
Visiting daughter and didn't have my recipe with me so I went by this one which is very similar to mine.  I used 1 cup of butter because we didn't have shortening and I really like the all butter recipe better anyway. We also didn't have cream of tartar so I substituted 2 teaspoons baking powder instead of the soda and cream of tartar.  The cookies turned out great...yummy, soft, chewy...but the tops didn't crack as much as usual, so that may have been from the substitutions.  I'm telling you this so if you want to make these cookies and don't have shortening and/or cream of tartar, you can still make them!

These were delicious, and two dozen cookies disappeared within half a day. I only had butter on hand, but it worked fabulously. Next time I make these (and there's already been requests for next time), I'll probably use a teaspoon less of the cream of tartar and a teaspoon more of the baking soda for a sweeter cookie.

text:
I made these snickerdoodles yesterday, and they were fantastic! My family and I normally don't like snickerdoodles; they are too "eggy" for our tastes.  But these were perfect. They were very soft, (and even softer the next day), and their edges are crisp. I baked my cookies for 8 minutes and they were perfect; the second batch baked at 8:30 came out with burnt bottoms.  Also, I chilled my dough in the freezer for about 10 minutes, and increased the cinnamon mixture to 3 tablespoons of sugar and three teaspoons cinnamon. I didn't use shortening; I used all butter, and had excellent results!

text:
This is a great recipe. . . not my favorite, though, because I prefer a chewier snickerdoodle. However, if you like a soft cookie, then this recipe is for you. I think next time I will leave them in the oven longer; heeding the warnings of other reviewers, I took them out at 8 minutes, and I think they may have been a bit undercooked. That being said, my advice would be to take into account how your oven behaves and judge accordingly. For me, 9 minutes was better, and I could have left them in longer. Anyways, the cookies were delicious :)

text:
I've made these cookies quite a few times, as they are my husband's favorite, and they've always turned out perfect. He requested them a few nights ago, and I was out of cream of tartar (which I didn't realize until after I'd started mixing things!). I searched for a substitute and ended up using 6 teaspoons of vinegar. I was extremely nervous, but I am happy to report that they came out just as amazing as usual -- with no hint of vinegar after they baked! These are a keeper, all around!!!

text:
I love these cookies! They are wonderful and a lot of fun to make. I followed the advice of one of the reviews and removed my first batch right at 8 minutes...DONT do that. I couldn't get the cookies off the sheet and half turned to moosh. The time to cook them depends on the size you make them, what kind of pan your using, ect. You're better off testing the times on your own. I ended up using more sugar/cinnamon mixture than called for too. All in all they are scrumtious! I will use this recipe over and over again.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Almost perfect! I followed the recipe exactly, but after reading the reviews, I did do the following: I bought brand new baking soda, just to be safe (mine was in date, but had been open for quite a while). I baked for 8 minutes exactly, and I pulled the cookies off of the cookie sheet after only a minute or so to make sure they didn't overcook. The result was snickerdoodles that were still nicely chewy even after three days! Pretty much my only disappointment was that they remained puffy. I've had bakery snickerdoodles before that flatten and get the nice crackled-top look, but still stay chewy, but every recipe I've tried has only been one or the other--flat and hard or puffy and chewy. Still, these taste great, so I'm not complaining!

country:
None
text:
These cookies were fabulous!  As suggested I hand mixed the batter, and the consistency turned out great.  I also added 3 TBS of sugar and 2 1/2 tsp of cinn in a ziplock bag and tossed the balls in (one at a time) to coat, it was a lot less messy then rolling on a plate, and coated way better.  8 minutes was the max to cook for!  The cookie should be cracked but still look wet on the inside.  Let it cool for a couple minutes on the sheet before transfering to a wire rack.  Really good cookie, with a nice mellow flavor and a nice chewy texture!

text:
The best snickerdoodle recipe ever!  I have been making these cookies for years now.  Instead of shortening I use all butter and roll my cookies in a brown sugar/cinnamon mix rather than white sugar & cinnamon.  Do not cook longer than 8/9 minutes or they will turn hard.  Cooking time is key, take out of the oven right after the little cracks appear and they will be perfect.  Amazing cookie!!!!

userID:

Display Name:
globalnomad
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5596139.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is my first Snickerdoodle recipe I've tried, and I have to say I am quite impressed.  The cookies come out with a nice crispy exterior, but the interior is so soft and chewy - JUST how I like my cookies.  And this was done even using a microwave oven and beating everything by hand!  I made them for my girlfriend who is a Snickerdoodle connoisseur so to speak, and she absolutely loves them.  The two changes I made in how I prepared them was to use baking powder instead of soda and cream of tarter, and to squash the cookies out more into a pancake form than a ball, as when in balls they didn't spread very much and as pancakes they still rose to be nice and poofy (this could be a result of using the microwave oven).  I've made cookies after freezing the batter and after leaving it in the refrigerator (the frozen version first).  I would definitely say the flavor holds better by freezing the extra batter (wrap it up tightly in plastic wrap and then put it in a ziplock bag).

text:
Ok i believe you now about taking them out at 8 min. Well actually mine hadn't started to "crackle" yet at 8 min so i left them in for the full 10. they looked pretty much raw in the cracks when i pulled them out but now that i'm eating them they are a little too done, so AS SOON as the start to crack take them out and leave them on the baking tray for a few minutes. Now, i had to do some substituting b/c i didn't have all the ingredients so heres what i did: was out of eggs so i used mayo instead also i don't buy cream of tarter so i did the baking powder and lemon juice substitute and they came out fine. Next time i won't cook so long.

None
text:
Great recipe!  Turned out perfect - crispy & chewy.  Use 4 Tablespoons sugar and 4 teaspoons cinnamon to roll the balls of dough in.  You'll have extra cinnamon/sugar in the end but it will make rolling the balls a lot easier.  DO NOT OVER BAKE.  Take the cookies out just before you think they're done.  Then let them cool a few minutes on the cookie sheet before removing them to a cooling rack.  My cookies were just right at 8 minutes.  Caution: Don't make these cookies if you're on a diet - you won't be able to eat just one.  This recipe is a keeper!

text:
This was an easy recipe that yielded delicious results!  I read the reviews about an acrid taste from the cream of tartar, so I reduced it to 1 tsp.  There was no chemical taste, but the cookies also ended up crunchier than I would've liked.  I will try again with the full amount of cream of tartar and see if that makes a difference.  Regardless of the texture, the flavor of these cookies was perfect, and my apartment smelled wonderful.

country:

text:
Today was my first time ever making snickerdoodles, but they turned out beautifully! At 400 I baked ONLY 8 minutes and they were perfect... I have a double oven (basically just 2 ovens one atop the other) and each was at 400 so i could bake 2 pans at a time, but one pan would be burning at 6 minutes! Then it hit me - that was using a DARK PAN! Use a light colored, nonstick pan!! They'll be perfect!! And to make it even easier, skip the greasing of the pan and just use PARCHMENT PAPER! It is a lifesaver for this recipe and all other cookie recipes!

text:
These are pretty good. I used less crisco and more butter to bring out the flavor. Also, you'll probably get 48 cookies if you use a tablespoon, but if you're making these for Christmas cookies to gift, if you use a teaspoon and bake for 7 minutes, you'll get close to 6 dozen.

text:
5+++ stars!
I made a few changes:

- Instead of 1/2 c shortening, use 1/4 c shortening + 3 tbsp of butter 

 -Add 1/4 tsp of baking powder 

These were the best snickerdoodles I've ever had, plus reducing the shortening made them taste less store-bought...soo good!!

text:
Sooooo..... I had to do these in two batches because I didn't realize that I didn't have enough vanilla and soda to make a full batch.  So I started half a batch and sent my husband to the store so that I could make a second, full batch after.  That first half-batch turned out GORGEOUS, just like the pictures.  Round and puffy.  NOT FLAT!!!  I whipped up the second batch exactly the same way, as the recipe was written, and to my dismay, they turned out flat!!!  I could tell they weren't going to be the same, because the dough seemed more flimsy and sort of sticky.  I have no idea why.  Once in between bakings I tried adding a little more soda, which helped a tad, but they never got back to that original puffiness.  So frustrating!!!  But still very good.  I'll try again with some suggestions from others on the "puffy factor".  Thanks for the recipe!!

text:
One reviewer recommended baking these no longer than eight minutes. My suggestion is test one batch, then decide. I baked an entire batch at eight minutes -- they were OK, but a little pale and not crisp. But the last batch (wouldn't you know it!) that got left in an extra minute turned out perfect -- lightly brown and crisp on the edges. I'll bake my next batch at nine minutes.

recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674168.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made some changes to this recipe and they were absolutely delicious! CHANGES: 3 cups flour, 1 tsp. cream of tarter & 1 tsp. baking powder, ALL shortening (butter flavored crisco) because I didn't have any butter, and I baked them for 8 minutes at 375. The shortening worked wonderfully and also made it so the dough was more manageable since it is somewhat more solid than butter at room temp. Not sticky at all! Soft, pillowy cookies that  my husband and I became instantly addicted to. If you like a slightly crispy on the outside snickerdoodle, then slightly press on the rounded balls before baking them. A flatter cookie will have a crisping effect (in this case anyway!). Enjoy :)

text:
These cookies are just about perfect--I would only suggest one minor alteration.  I added a bag of cinnamon chips to the dough before rolling out the cookies, and this made them even more perfect by adding an extra touch of spice.  I definitely agree with the other reviewers about cooking time--do not leave them in the oven any longer than eight minutes, even if they don't look quite done.  They set up quite nicely once you take them out and put them on racks.

These are pretty good, but I think there may be too much cream of tartar.  I noticed an aftertaste.  Besides that, though, they were good.  I used all butter and part whole wheat pastry flour.  I got exactly 3 dozen out of the recipe.  I took reviewer's advice and used 3 tsp. sugar and 3 TBS cinnamon, but I had some leftover so I'm not sure I needed that much. ***** Tried these the day after baking and can't taste the cream of tartar anymore!  They are 5 star now.  ;)

text:
Absolutely a favorite at home, work and with the neighbors!  I mix the dry and wet ingredients separately.  Cream together the wet ingredients with the mixer and mix in the dry ingredients with a wooden spoon.  With my oven, I set it at 380 degrees and bake for 8 minutes, then I let the cookies rest for 1-2 minutes on the sheet and then transfer to the cooling rack.

None
text:
I can't believe it's taken me this long to rate this recipe. I used to be a chocolate chip cookie kind of girl, but after making these once, I will never invest effort into making cookies unless they are snickerdoodles. 
Some hints: 
It's a lot easier to put the cinnamon and sugar coat into a ziplock bag and just shake the snickerdoodles in them... that way you can coat them thoroughly with ease. 
For all of those who say these have an aftertaste: you are not coating them properly. That aftertaste is the cinnamon. Solved by the ziplock method mentioned above, and make sure it's coated well.

text:
I love cinnamon, so when I saw this recipe had been rated so many times I had to give it a try.  I've had snickerdoodles before but never made them myself so I have no other recipes to compare this one to, but they were really good.  After experimenting with the baking time I realized one minute more or less can make a big difference.  When making the cinnamon sugar mixture I thought the ration of cinnamon to sugar looked a bit much, so I left the cinnamon amount the same and added 2 Tbsp more of sugar.  I think still more sugar would have been good.  I used my Kitchenaide mixer on these cookies and they were great, not overmixed whatsoever.  They didn't look quite as crackly as the allrecipes photo, but they were still beautiful.

text:
I feel like my review does not count for much since there is already over a thousand reviews!!!!  But I pretty much echo what y'all have said.  This is the best snickerdoodle recipe ever.  I bake about 5 times a week, every week, every month, every year.  I collect recipes like crazy and put all of my favorites into a "special" folder.  This is definitely one of my favorites.  It's what a true snickerdoodle is supposed to be.  Crispy on the outside edges, slightly chewy on the inside, not real puffy with a wonderful flavor.  I do add a bit more sugar to my rolling bowl but besides that I follow the recipe to a T.  In fact, I add some sparkly sanding sugar to the rolling sugar and it adds a small sparkle.  Gosh, these are tasty.  I just now made a triple recipe and I guarantee you they will disappear quickly.  I highly recommend this recipe as your standard snickerdoodle recipe.

text:
These were good.  Although next time I might use more butter and less shortening.  They had a strong flavor of shortening that I particularly don't care for.  I followed some suggestions from prior reviews, I decreased the oven temp just a tad and baked for exactly 8 minutes, cooled for 1 minute on baking sheet then placed on wire racks to cool completely.  They were slightly crisp on the outside and soft inside.  I also upped the cinnamon/sugar mix and dumped it all into a plastic baggie and coated the dough that way.  To someone who said you must mix by hand... I used my Kitchenaid stand mixer and the cookies turned out fine.  Overall, a nice recipe, Thanks!

text:
The taste is amazing, but for some reason my results are inconsistent with this one and I don't know why.  The first time I made these they were flawless; I was looking forward to making them again, but when I did they just wouldn't spread!  I used the fork method to press them.  They were still delicious, though.  Be very careful with the cooking time!  A few minutes is all the difference between a yummy, chewy snickerdoodle and one that is rock-hard with burnt cinnamon!  Watch them carefully.

text:
This made very attractive classically "cracked" snickerdoodles but were not chewy and turned out too cake-like in the middle of the cookie for my taste. I took the advice of other reviewers and creamed the butter and sugar by hand. It probably made a difference in the appearance (didn't flatten out during baking) but may have kept them from being chewy since the electric mixer would have probably creamed the mixture better than I did. Next time I would go ahead and use the mixer just to cream the butter and sugar and let the dough rest overnight.

text:
These were delicious, especially after they were completely cooled.  I used a hand mixer and replaced the baking soda and cream of tartar with 4tsp of baking powder.  The first  batch I didn't flatten and they were very domed and a little raw in the middle.  The second batch I flattened and indented the middles so they would rise evenly, worked like a charm.  I ended up with 26 cookies.

text:
My first time baking these traditional favorites was a success. I can't find shortening in Finland (is there a substitute?), so I used a whole cup of butter instead. I also substituted vinegar for the cream of tartar (also cannot find in supermarkets here). Otherwise, the suggestions of using a bag to shake the dough balls in and using exactly 8 minutes in the oven were perfect. They may not LOOK done, but if you want them to be slightly chewy on the inside, take them out despite that they aren't browned. Trust me.

text:
I followed this recipe exactly, except that I used light butter instead of margarine.  I don't know if my butter was too soft, or if I stirred the ingredients a bit too much (and my daughter, who helped me and insisted on sirring a lot) but the batter was too thin and gooey to be rolled into balls.  So, I plopped the batter by the spponful onto the cookies sheets and sprinkled with the sugar & cinnamon mixture.  The flavor, taste, and texture is still delicious, but it is surely not how I expected it to be, especially after seeing the photos here, and also knowing what snickerdoodles should look and taste like.  I will save this recipe and try again, maybe using margarine, or regular butter, and not letting the butter soften as much, and also not stirring so briskly. Thanks for the great recipe!

text:
Having never eaten, let alone baked, snickerdoodles, I am very happy with hos this recipe turned out.  I bake with butter-flavored shortening, no matter the ingredients called for, and decided to stick with that instead of the butter & shortening prescribed.  It worked beautifully.  The only adjustment I'll make next time is in the cinnamon-sugar coating.  I'll use raw sugar instead of regular white sugar to add some texture and I'll decrease the amount of cinnamon as I thought these were a bit heavy.  But totally great otherwise.

My husband isn't a cookie person and he went back three times for more.  This recipe has earned a spot in my recipe box.

text:
These were simple and delicious.  I used a little more sugar and cinnamon to shake them in a ziploc bag.  I used a cookie scoop and simply dropped into the bag, let my 3-year-old shake, and placed them on my cookie sheet with Reynold's Release Foil - this has been a miracle for my cookies.  I did cut the cooking time down to 7 minutes because I like it a little chewey in the middle.  They looked great too!

country:
None
text:
This is a GREAT recipe for snickerdoodles and it scales down very nicely.  The only thing I would suggest is not to completely roll them in the cinnamon sugar because the sugar on the bottom of the cookie will burn a bit while cooking, making the bottoms of the cookies tougher.. so next time, I would dip the cookie dough balls into the cinnamon sugar, just being careful not to coat the bottoms.  
Also, you gotta pull them out and place them on a cooling rack as soon as they come out for nice and soft cookies.

I wasn't all that crazy about these and I LOVE to bake and eat cookies..they didn't seem to flatten out as much as I would have liked and i didn't care much for the cinn/sugar coating (too much cinnamon)  Followed recipe as written and baked for 8 minutes only. text:
These cookies are delicious! Just as they are described - crispy outside, soft & chewy inside. Mmmmm! I agree with other reviewers to use 3 TBS sugar to 2 tsp cinnamon. Baking them 9-10 minutes in my oven worked the best (8 minutes came out a little undercooked). This recipe is a definite keeper!

text:
12/20/2006: Snickerdoodles are just about the only cookie that my Uncle David likes. He LOVED these and asked if I would make a batch for him as a Christmas gift! You may need to adjust the amount of time these spend in the oven. I had to bake mine just a little bit longer to get them "just right".

UPDATE 12/17/2015: I've been making these 9 years and they never fail. Tonight I checked them at *exactly* 8 minutes and they were perfect.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My friend described the taste as: fluffy cookie dough with a crisp touch of sugar cinnamon, and she was bang on!! When you taste raw chocolate chip cookie dough, it tastes different than the actual baked cookie..But this cookie has basically a pure cookie dough taste in its baked form.  A very simply and light not overly sweet cookie. Make sure you keep an eye on them while baking. I baked a batch for 9 minutes and the bottoms burnt so fast! Next tray I baked for 8 minutes and they were perfect. My cookies, however, did not have that cracked looking top that many of the submitted recipe photes have. My cookies were farely smooth looking but still had that crisp outside texture. I followed the recipe exactly too. I might try chilling the dough next time as some users suggested

text:
These cookies are good.  I would suggest making well rounded teaspoon full size or even tablespoon size because I thought the "spoonful" meant teaspoon size and the cookies were barely bite size.
Can't understand the problem folks had with the cream of tartar -ever recipe I've ever made for Snickerdoodles calls for cream of tartar.
I only gave this recipe four stars because although I thought the cookies were tasty it's not my favorite recipe.  IMHO, the recipe in the Better Homes & Gardens cook book is my long time favorite.

text:
I liked the flavor of this cookie a lot, but let me give you some background.  I cannot cook cookies.  I have no idea why, but I can never get any cookie to turn out the way it should.  And this recipe, once again proved I have no business baking cookies.  The dough was way too sticky to roll into a ball.  I followed the directions exactly and they ended up being paper thin.  The flavor is great, but they are too greezy, and buttery.  I doubt I will make these again.  I'm doubting if I will ever make any cookie again.  But if you want carmel pecan yeast cinnamon rolls, or a 4 tier wedding cake, I can make those, no problem at all!  HA!

Display Name:
AUSSIEMUM1

45

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/23546.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I followed the recipe except for the fact that I used all butter instead of shortening. I creamed the butter and sugar by machine as a busy mum I could not be bothered to do it by hand. I folded the flour in. The dough tasted fine uncooked and I just pinched off pieces and rolled with fingertips into balls, put them in a plastic bag with cinnamon/sugar mix and shook it around. My oven cooked these at 11 mins, because at 8 the centers were still wet. The reason this has four stars is because now that the cookies are cool, there is an overwhelming eggy taste to the cookies. You know when you can really taste egg? I don't know why this is so because 2 eggs are not really an excess amount of egg. Next time, I would use 1 egg and sub with 1 teaspoon of egg substitute powder. I lifted the cookie sheets straight out of the tray to cool instead of trying to lift them with a spatula. I will make these again and play with the recipe, maybe add some orange peel or something and less real egg.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Delicious cookies!!! I did find out the hard way about the debate of cooking time.  My first batch I cooked for 8 mins then immediately put on wire rack to cool. They did not look cooked enough. I ate one soon after.  The cookie was as I thought, not cooked enough in middle.  The next 3 batches I cooked 9 mins.  This was a mistake: THESE COOKIES FIRM ALL THE WAY THROUGH WHEN THEY ARE THOROUGHLY COOL. I don't have enough cookie baking experience to know if all cookies firm like this when cool. But my 8 min batch is the yummy crispy on outside, chewy on inside cookie.  The 9 min batch is still tasty, yet drier on the inside.

text:
I made this recipe without using butter and replaced it with natural without transfat margarine because my daughter is super allergic to dairy. I also used transfat free shortening by crisco, and it still turned out yummy: chewy and crispy. I think the key is the shortening. Also, I added about 1/4 cup less of sugar. The recipe I did was 48 cookies, but I was only able to get only 2 dozen out of it, not sure if it was because I took some sugar out, and changed the butter out, but I didn't think it would make that much of a difference! In any case, great recipe! I am always trying to change it up to cut the dairy out, and so far, every receipe I tried including this one on this site has all worked nicely.

text:
This recipe is fairly idiot-proof (yet I managed to mess it up by using baking powder instead of baking soda. Oops... it still turned out delicious though.) While not nearly as flat/crackly as I would have liked... that was probably my mistake. 9 minutes came out to the perfect cookie. They seem a little undercooked right out of the oven but get a good deal crispier as they cool. Like other reviews said, I would use equal parts sugar and cinnamon to roll the dough in. We only rolled the tops and sides, not the bottom and it turned out fine. Great cookies that were eaten up in a day! Everything you would want in a snickerdoodle.

The taste is wonderful, although baking the cookies at 400 degrees always burns the bottoms of my cookies. I think it might just be me oven!
Also, the diections are misleading. I've found that if I roll the cookies in the cinnamon and sugar mixture and bake them, the cookies bun on the bottoms. Instead I only roll the tops of the balls of dough in the mixture.
Otherwise, my favorite Snickerdoodle recipe so far!

These are great!  I have been using a recipe for these that is almost exactly the same but it uses all crisco instead of half crisco half butter.  They are really good either way, but I think the dough is a little easier to work with using this one.  I baked these for 7 min in my oven and I got 42 cookies, plus I ate some dough :).  Don't overbake snickerdoodles, or they'll be great right out of the oven, but hard as a rock when they cool.

text:
Wonderful recipe.  This is my very favorite snickerdoodle recipe.  I don't use any other because this cookie has the best flavor.  A word of caution: do not overcook.  The cookies can go from being deliciously soft and almost chewy to being hard as a rock in just a short while if you don't watch them carefully.  This recipe, however, is amazing.

text:
8 minutes baking time was perfect. The dough is very soft, so i used a tablespoon to scoop out even amounts, i turned the "scoop" upside down into the cinnamon sugar mix and then scoop the cookie dough out of that tablespoon with a regular spoon so that the cinnamon sugar mix would stay on top. It was really easy and they all came out about the same size.

text:
It might just be that we are not snicker doodle people, but this would not be a first choice cookie recipe for me to make again.  For those who want to try this recipe, I can tell you that a minute does make a difference!  At least in my oven.  I baked two batches - one at 8 minutes and one at 9 minutes exactly.  The 8 minute cookies had a chewier center (which I preferred) and the 9 minute cookies had a crispier center (which my husband preferred). Oh well...you five star people probably know how to bake them better than I do.

text:
My 5 year old is allergic to eggs and dairy so I wasn't sure how this recipe would turn out using Egg Replacer.  To my surprise they turned out beautifully.  I halved the recipe substituting one stick of soy margarine for the 1/4 c. of butter and shortening and I was able to make 15 nice size cookies.  My son couldn't wait long enough for the cookies to cool and ate 3 right away!  He, along with my husband who is not a heavy sweet eater, loved them and I will be making more tonight.  Thank you for a great recipe that I will be making over and over again!

text:
These are awesome! I used a small disher then dropped the dough directly in a bowl with cinnamon and sugar (way more than the recipe calls for) and rolled the balls around a few at a time. I would definitely reccomend this method since you don't have to get your hands sticky and the cookies are always the exact same time. I went the max cook time, they were kind of gross in the middle if it went below that.

text:
My 7 year old wanted to make some snickerdoodles because he likes grandma's snickerdoodles so much.  I let him do all the measuring and put all the ingredients in the mixing bowl.  I formed the balls and he rolled them in the cinnamon sugar and put them on the baking sheet.  We didn't modify the recipe at all and they came out of the oven tasting delicious.  No cream of tarter bitterness as some others have reported.  Perhaps better ingredients yield better results, but this recipe makes an excellent snickerdoodle.

Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2005-12-17T15:15:28.763
helpfulCount:
1
userID:
1452636
Display Name:
TUNISIANSWIFE
isPro:
False
followersCount:
141

0

431
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/933710.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I am ambivilent on the rating here...I would really rate it a 3.5.  I followed the recipe exactly and they came together nicely.  I too had to use more of the cinnamon/sugar coating.  I used a small cookie scoop and dropped them with that into the sugar mixture for rolling; that way I didn't have to handle them.  I rolled them around in the bowl and onto the tray.  I could taste a slight aftertaste of the cream of tarter.  I would suggest NOT using 'AIRBAKE' cookiesheet for these.  I have one airbake and one regular cookie sheet and the airbaked batches came out flat and didn't look like a snickerdoodle.  I think the high heat is needed for them to puff and crack on top.  the airbake cookies came out rather flat and resembled an oatmeal cookie.  I would also suggest using a good cinnamon for these...I had a cheap "dollar store" brand and I couldn't taste the cinnamon at all.  I rolled them completely and had no trouble with burning; they were beautifully golden on the bottom.  I had to come back here the next day and add to this review:  after letting them set for 24 hours they taste like a doodle with no aftertaste of bitterness and the cinnamon flavor is there but not overwhelming.  They are also very crisp on the edges....I've upgraded rating to 4 stars.

text:
These are really delicious. Crispy around the edge, chewy in the middle. It all came together very quickly too. I made them as written, except I chilled the dough for about 15 minutes before rolling the balls. The dough was very easy to handle and the ziploc baggie made it easy to coat them with the cinn/sugar. I used a convection oven at 380 for 7 minutes on dark nonstick pans. Definitely will make these again.

city:

None
country:
None
text:
The best snickerdoodle recipe I've baked, as long as you bake at 375 for exactly 8 minutes. The texture is perfect. 
I'm also tasting a bit too much cream of tartar, but no one else in my family seems to notice... 
I also use only about half to 3/4 teaspoon of cinnamon per tablespoon of sugar when rolling -- I find a whole teaspoon of cinnamon per is too strong for my taste.
Once baked, these freeze very well (and defrost quickly, so you can sneak one or two or six while no one's looking!).

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've tried other snickerdoodle recipes without any success (too flat, no flavour etc) but finally found my be-all, end-all snickerdoodle recipe right here! I didn't have cream of tartar so I omitted it along with the baking soda and used 1 tablespoon of baking powder. Also used 1 cup of white sugar w/ 1/2 cup brown sugar and 3 tbsp white sugar w/ 3 tsp of cinnamon to roll dough in. I did have to turn my oven to 375 (my oven gets really hot!) and baked for 8 minutes. I ate at least half a dozen right when they came out of the oven and hubby took some to work today and said they're requesting more! The cookies stayed nice and soft even though I forgot to close the container they were in. This is definitely "the" snickerdoodle recipe to try!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made these twice in the last week! I sent some to a girlfriend in the upstairs apartment, but her husband ate them all before she came home!  The first time I made them, I didn't have shortening on hand and used all margerine.  The second time I made them, I followed the recipe exactly.  Both batches were delicious, but the margerine made the cookies soft, rather than chewy.  Definitely use shortening for a chewy texture.  Either way, they melt in your mouth.  Try not to roll balls bigger than an inch in diameter, and slightly flatten them if using margerine.  Otherwise they will be too puffy. Now I can't decide whether these or The Whole Jar of Peanut Butter Cookies are my favorite.  Happy baking! Yum

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674139.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I followed the recipe as written, with the exception of adding an additional tsp of vanilla as suggested by another reviewer.  I rolled one batch into balls, rolled them in sugar, then pressed them slightly onto the cookie sheet (covered with parchment paper) with the bottom of a glass.  These came out of the oven looking "perfect", but were quite thin.  The next batch I rolled into balls, and then just baked them without flattening first. They weren't as pretty, but they weren't as thin either.  Both seemed as though they would get harder as they cooled, but I sealed them in an airtight container and they remained soft and chewy.  The taste was delicious...I could not taste an tartar at all.  Everybody liked them but weren't overly enthusiastic about them.  Nice change from the standard chocolate chip.  Thanks for sharing!

text:
Unbelievable!  Oddly enough, generally I don't like Snickerdoodles but I made these b/c they are an excellent pairing for hot tea (just one or two for a cup).  My husband also does not care for Snickerdoodles...he's not a huge sweet person, but Snickerdoodles were also always too crispy for him.  He ate SIX of these within 30 minutes!  They were soft, perfectly spiced and had a nice barely perceptable hint of salt that kept the cookie from being too sweet.  I had to send these to work with him to keep myself from eating them all the time, and they were completely consumed within a matter of minutes.  Makes the top five in my cookie recipes.

text:
I halved the recipe and used all butter instead of shortening & 2 tsp. white vinegar in place of 1 tsp. crm of tartar since I didn't have any.   As others, I lowered temp to 375 & took out in 8 min. when they still look light and just starting to crack on the surface.  Resulted in a somewhat dry, soft, cake-like cookie. I think better results(crispier) would be w/ exact recipe. Still Yummy!!

text:
My daughter and her friends made these for youth group, and everyone loved them.  One of the boys came up to her later and told her these were better than his girlfriend makes, and he loves her snickerdoodles.  He relayed that these stayed nice and soft for days without careful sealing.  Ours didn't last long enough to find out.  The girls did substitute lemon juice for the cream of tartar, and there was no bitterness.

This recipe is PERFECT and a snap!

I've read a lot of the reviews saying they scorch, need parchment etc....

Know your oven and use good cookware.  They came right off the cookie sheet in perfect condition.

The recipe is PERFECT!  My only complaint is that it doesn't make enough!  :)  My family gobbled them all down as fast as I could make them.

These are delicious with a very delicate flavor.  My kids loved helping and especially enjoyed eating them. Otherwise, they would've been too hard.

A neighbor had made a batch of these for my children.  They loved them so much that I had to ask for the recipe.  We made a double batch for each of my children's classes for Christmas. I made a lot of substitutes so my sister cook to eat it. Instead of butter and shortening, I used 1 cup of coconut oil. Then instead of eggs, I used 1/2 cup of applesauce. Then instead of flour, I used Red Mills 1 to 1 baking flour (gluten-free flour). I also added roughly about 2 teaspoons of cinnamon in the cookie dough.

text:
I don't find them as amazing as everyone says they are,especially straight from the oven. They are nice and soft but lack flavor. Maybe they need to sit for a while for the flavor to really dog in. So I will wait and update of there is any change.  I followed the recipe as its and did have to as about 1/4c floor to unstuck the surface. But I realized that with a cookie scoop it wouldn't have mattered; because the cinnamon sugar costing would have covered the stickiness. Maybe that is part of the lack of flavor,or maybe it's the .25tsp of salt.
So next time I'll go the salt to.5tsp. It is a workable recipe. I think I want to try it with all butter as well. Maybe I should have used salted butter,but the author did not specify...

city:
