region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used several tips from the reviews: increased flower to a scant 3 cups, left out about half of one egg white (so used 2 yolks and 1.5 whites), reduced heat to 375. I also used a full tbsp of vanilla, and added a bit of cardamom to the sugar mixture for a more complex flavor. They took 10 minutes instead of 8 to cook, but came out wonderfully - puffy and soft with just a little crisp to the outside.

text:
Loved these cookies, made exactly per Mrs Sigg's instructions except removing from sheet immediately. I tried removing a cookie right out of the oven and it fell apart. I let the cookies rest on the sheets for 2 min and they were easily removed from the sheet and placed on the cooling racks , only thing I will change in the recipe is increase the white sugar in the cinnamon coating from 2 tbl to  3 tbl as the cinnamon is a bit strong in this one. These cookies as is are Amazing !!!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I make these year after year and it's always such a tried and true recipe. they're so perfectly soft that it makes people smile when they take the first bite :)
I usually don't keep cream of tartar on hand bc subbing with lemon juice has never failed me in any recipe and works the same - so don't feel the need to go out and buy some if you don't have any. 
pro tip: for perfectly soft cookies, take them out of the oven at 8 min, but let them stay on the baking tray for a few minutes so it continues slightly baking on the pan. up to 9 min is okay but I'd say that 10 is too long if you want maximum tenderness! ;)

text:
Love these, but for me it seems to take a couple batches to figure out perfect cooking time and perfect size of cookies.
NOTE TO SELF: 1) Next time don't rely on "ungreased cookies sheet". USE PARCHMENT paper - my cookies stuck to the cookie sheet thus ruining my first 2 batches.  2) Roll dough into 1-inch balls, small is good. Too big and they flatten way out.
Yummy.

I used parchment paper for baking on.  NINE minutes and not a  half minute more!.  (I scorched one batch - which my husband devoured anyway.) text:
Oh boy is this yummy!!! Crispy edges and chewy center. Absolutely delicious!

I didn't have cream of tartar so I subbed it for baking powder (also learned vinegar could be used instead). Also used all butter.

It's a super simple recipe and easy to follow. I creamed butter and everything else for 5 mins then used a wooden spoon to blend in the dry ingredients.

Will be making this over and over again.

text:
I doubled the recipe so I could freeze the dough for the holidays and after reading suggestions I used 2 teaspoons cream of tartar, and 2 teaspoons baking powder and 2 teaspoons baking soda. The cream of tartar kept the cracks in the cookies on top and the baking powder kept them from being totally flat. They turned out perfect as long as I followed reviews and took them out at 8 minutes even though they didn’t look quite done yet at the time. I let them firm up for a couple of minutes on the cookie sheet. They’re amazingly good!

userID:
15660508
Display Name:
Diana Briscoe
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2226502.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I followed the recipe as written and the final result was perfect. I rolled the dough into 48 little balls (the recommended size in the recipe)  and tossed them in a bag of sugar/cinnamon mix and placed them on the foil. I did not flatten them.  I did not chill the dough.  I baked at 400 degrees for exactly 8 minutes.  Then I immediately slid the foil sheet onto the counter to cool for a few minutes.

They puffed up and spread to maybe 2 1/2 inches wide and about a half inch tall.  They settled only slightly after cooling. They are not at all dry or crunchy.  Just slightly chewy.

I think that it is important to really cream the butter and sugar and eggs until fluffy.  That helps a lot to prevent too much spreading while baking. Do not worry about "over fluffing", that is not possible. 

I do not use a baking sheet to bake cookies.  I use a cookie cooling rack and lay a piece of foil over it.  Then I quickly slide the foil with the cookies off the rack when I take it out of the oven.  Perfectly colored cookie bottoms and the rack is cool enough to use with the next batch of cookies.  This way I get the exact same baking conditions for every pan that I bake.  I just use two sheets of foil and rotate them after I remove the cooled cookies. I also do not grease the sheets.

If you like Snickerdoodles, follow the recipe carefully, you  will be rewarded with perfect cookies.

5

text:
You know how you dont get flat cookies?! Cream the out of the butter shortening egg and vanilla!  I mean for like at least 5 mins. You want to make sure that is nice and fluffy not just mearly mixed. 

I baked mine got 10 mins at 400 degrees and they still came out absolutely delicious!  Puffy and soft. 

One thing is that next time I may try using unsalted butter to try to cut down on the salt in the cookie. Even with the salted butter, the cookie is delicious.

text:
I’ve been making this recipe for years as it appeared in Southern Living many, many years ago. However, the original called for 1 cup of shortening and no butter. I’ve always made them with shortening until today. I tried half butter. These cookies did not puff up and stay puffed like the shortening ones. These deflated and turned out quite “sad”. They also seem greasy. I know butter is “healthier” but not the best for these cookies. I’m going back to shortening.

text:
These are an all-time family favorite.  Both my son and my grandson have enjoyed participating in the creation of our snickerdoodles.  Their roles:  Job 1 was to shake the ball around in the cinnamon/sugar mixture, and Job 2 was to watch the batch through the oven window.  We found we liked the cookie best if I removed them from the oven just after they deflated.  When that occurred, he would shout, "There they go!", and that was my signal to remove them.   They would be a little crispy around the edges, and a little chewy in the middle. Yum!

text:
Made half a batch and they turned out beautifully. In place of shortening I used the shelf-stable Crisco which can be used to replace butter or shortening; for the softened butter, I went with the Smart Balance version used for cooking and baking. Added a pinch of ginger to the cinnamon and sugar used to roll the dough. I love the soft middle while it remains slightly crunchy on the outside, especially around the edges. I can see me trying these out again.

userID:
24798841
Display Name:
anshpo
isPro:

followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
2

3
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674145.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I added 3/4 C flour, changed baking soda to 1 1/2 tsp and cream of tartar to 1 1/2 tsp.  Refrigerated dough for 20 mins and rolled into rough balls before dipping in sugar and cinnamon. Cookies were thick and pillowy, crispy outside. The best snickerdoodle recipe I have ever tried. I've made it twice now. Changed the baking soda and cream of tartar cut down on the acrid taste you can get sometimes with tartar. Adding the flour and refrigerating made the dough easier to handle and rise for a thicker cookie that doesnt spread out so much.

5

text:
I made this to take to a family Christmas party. They are wonderful! The only change I made was substituting baking powder for the cream of tartar because I didn't have any. Be sure not to over bake them!! I pulled them out of the oven a little early and let them residually cook on the baking sheet for a minute or two. They are wonderfully soft and chewy out of the oven. My husband and children love them. I can't wait to see what the rest of the family thinks!

text:
They were gone an hour after they came out of the oven! My advice would be when putting them on the cookie sheet to make them into cubes and coat them with the cinnamon-sugar mixture and then put them in the oven for 9 minutes. I tried 8 minutes after reading the reviews and tried one but thought it was to wet and needed more time. I did 9 minutes and they were perfect. I will be bringing them to plenty of parties in the future! Another tip is to have fresh as possible baking soda and cream of tartar.

text:
I followed the advice of Chef Joy and pulled them from oven at 8 minutes.  I let them sit for a few minutes on pan before transferring to wire rack.  For the sugar coating; I mixed 3 Tbsp sugar and 2 1/2 tsp cinnamon (Chef Joy's tip) and this was just enough.   These freeze well also;  I made the balls, rolled in the sugar, put on a dish in the freezer for about 15 minutes and then dropped the balls in to a ziplock bag with the name; oven temp and time   Now I can bake a few at a time for the family

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2061833.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe was super easy to put together. I accidentally used a 1/2tbsp measuring spoon for vanilla so I wound up with 3tsp instead of 2. It didnt turn out bad at all even with that flub. Everything followed in this recipe was perfect- the ingredients, oven temp, duration. I got about 40 cookies out of the dough- I would recommend to refrigerate or freeze for just a few minutes to stiffen the dough a tad and make them stick less when rolling into balls. Mine were a bit fluffy, more of a dome than flat, which i like. Assuming if you prefer flatter cookies, you may want to give an easy pat down to flatten a bit before baking. These are kid-approved!

A very rounded, easy to make cookie. I used this recipe in my baking class and it turned out to perfection.  The only amendments we made to this recipe were to ever so slightly flatten them with a bowl so the didn't loose their bulk, but so they could spread more evenly. In addition, we adjusted the cooking time from 8 to 9 minutes, but every oven is different. Very well executed.

Display Name:
Misty Berry

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/547916.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I did not change a thing about this recipe and the cookies turned out great. I have a gas oven and I baked the cookies on the center rack for eight minutes. I used approximately one and a half inch dough balls for each cookie and placed them on a parchment lined baking pan.  The cookies stayed plump with soft insides and crusty edges. I was able to move them immediately from the pan onto the cooling rack. The shape was more uniform when I tightly rolled the dough balls. I will definitely use this recipe again. Delicious and easy!
Review:
Rating:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614248.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These turned out perfectly! Super fluffy. Crunchy on the edges and soft in the center. I don’t like cooking with shortening so I substituted it with the same amount of butter. The mixture was really sticking so I added an extra 1/2 cup of flour. It helped with the structure. It was still too sticky to roll in a ball however so I just used an ice cream scoop to scoop up the cookie dough into good sizes and put them on the sheet. After that, I sprinkled on my cinnamon sugar mixture. I made about 27 cookies with this recipe (my cookies were fairly large and expanded a good deal).

country:
None
text:
These turned out great. I didn't have shortening and used all butter. I also took other reviewers advise and used 3TBSP sugar and 2TSP cinnamon for the amounts you roll the dough in. The trick to fluffy cookies is DO NOT over mix. In every step, mix until just combined...be gentle with your dough and you will have wonderful cookies. I will be making these again as requested by all my kids. I used a cookie scoop and cooked them about 10 min as they were bigger cookies.

text:
I did only half of the recipe for around 20 cookies. Because I live in high altitude I had to make a few adjustments: a little less sugar, a little more flour. I had no cream of tartar so i use lemon juice. I also use canola oil instead of shortening. I put the unbaked cookies in the fridge for 30 minutes. I baked them as indicated in the recipe and they turned out perfect.

These are the best ever! I love them! I don’t use tartar most times though. It could have been using tartar or a little too much butter that made them flat and chewy once. text:
They were super good. I did tweak he recipe. You should def add cream of tartar for a better “eye appeal”. I also add just a light dust of the cinnamon and sugar mixture AFTER the cookies have baked as well. I do feel the bake time should be reduced and/or lengthened IF yhe size of your cookies aren’t spot-on with what the recipe says they should be. Delicious and I’ve added this to my cookie recipe book (with my hidden tweaks on there lol)

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was one of the best cookie recipes I've ever made!  I guess that's not saying much as I hardly ever bake, but I wanted to make something special for my Dad and brother-in-law for Father's Day.  

A couple of things I learned/tips: the scoop they use in the video is NOT an ice cream scoop!  It's a melon baller!  I made the cookies "too big" and they took twice as long to bake.  Overall not a bad thing though!  Just fewer but bigger cookies.  Also, I tried to cook both sheets at once, and the ones on the top rack almost got burnt but luckily are still edible!

Overall, I will definitely be making these again!  Not too hard for a novice/beginner baker like myself.

text:
This is the best snickerdoodle recipe I have found! Only thing is the first time I made them they did have a faint acidic, cream of tartar taste which was slightly unpleasant.  The next time I just substituted the baking soda and cream of tartar for 4 tsp. baking powder. This took away the bad aftertaste and the cookies were perfect! I will definitely  make these again!

Display Name:
Fleabite

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677179.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
What a wonderful recipe!  I followed the recipe exactly as written except I followed the suggestion of several reviewers and only cooked for eight minutes.  I also made sure to start with room temperature butter and shortening.  I did not use parchment paper as some suggested.  The cookies still came right off the sheet with no problem.  I moved them almost immediately to the cooling rack.  It was concerning that reviewers  worked around the gooey dough and I thought this might be messy - but it wasn't.  Just dust your hands with a bit of flour when rolling the balls.  I also rolled them by hand in a soup bowl containing the sugar/cinnamon mixture.  It was a lot less labor intensive than I thought it would be.  This recipe was made for a fundraiser and it doubled just fine.  You can move a batch to the cooling rack,  roll a pan/batch, and transfer a batch to baggies in about eight minutes.

text:
i've never made snickerdoodles before and decided to give this recipe a try. I don't think I've ever had so many compliments on a cookie recipe before! I followed the recipe exactly and baked for exactly 8 minutes like other reviewers said. I was worried they were underdone but once they cooled, they were perfectly crispy on the outside and so moist and chewy on the inside! They have a lovely vanilla flavour. My only complaint was I didn't know how big to make the balls. (I wish it said in the recipe) I got 28 cookies out of the recipe, and reading the reviews someone else got 64!!! 
I highly, highly recommend this recipe!

text:
I made three batches. Tried the original recipe, the cookies turned out rather well. Used a full cup of shortening for the next batch since I had used up my butter in another recipe, the cookies came out decently, lacked a little something. I bought more ingredients and forgot the shortening, so I used a whole cup of butter. This last batch turned out fantastic! A whole cup of butter, rather than half made the best cookies I have had in a long time. A richer flavour, and very tender, careful when taking them off the pan. I advise letting them set for a minute or two after putting the cookie sheet on a cool surface, marble, granite, or butcher block. otherwise the cookies will keep cooking and turn hard and taste *off* a little

This is the same basic Snickerdoodle recipe you will find floating all over the web. The only real difference in this one is the shortening. I skipped that and just used all butter. photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/745644.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
First of all, Cream of Tartar is used in the Snickerdoodle recipe for the distinctive tangy flavor that most Snickerdoodles have. If you do not like that flavor then do not use the Cream of Tartar. Most regular sugar cookies do not have any Cream of Tarter in them. If you want a cookie that raises more then increase the  baking soda or add baking powder. My grandmother used to use all Criso when making sugar cookies. I like using a combination of butter and shortening but using just shortening is possible if you do not want to wait for butter to come to room temperature. This is a good recipe. It's a matter of preference  whether you use Cream of Tarter or not. Personally, to me, it is not a Snickerdoodle without the Cream of Tarter.

3

city:

country:
None
text:
Terrific recipe! I baked with exact ingredients and — after reading some reviews — I only tweaked the  dipping sugar/cinnamon mix, and the temperature. For rolling the cookie balls prior to baking, I meant to add 1 extra Tbl of sugar & 1 tsp. cinnamon, but actually did 3 Tbl. of each. They're delicious this way if you like cinnamon! Not a requirement though. And since Chef Joy's review and a few others cautioned about the cookies getting too crispy if left too long, I first tried 375F for 10 minutes. The first batch came out perfect — rather moist looking on the inside but completely set on the outside. The cookies cook a little more as they cool off. I found 375F for 10 minutes to be  perfect for my oven! They were moist, thick and delicious. We've been eating these cookies around the clock since! Not too sweet, but sweet enough.

text:
These cookies are delicious, and super easy to make - just follow the recipe.  I used a standard size cookie scoop and split each scoop into two equal-sized balls, hand rolled and coated in the cinnamon/sugar mix.  I found that cutting the size in half made for a better snackable size cookie.  I'd give these 4.5 stars because they turned out a little airy/crunchier than I'd prefer - I like my cookies crisp on the outside and chewy/dense on the inside, and I was missing the chewiness factor.  Perhaps because I baked them for a full 8 mins even though I made smaller doodles.  I chalk that up to baker error, and will just reduce the baking time the next time I make them.  Yum!

text:
These are my favorite snickerdoodles! Better than any store- bought by far! 
The only note I would make is, DO NOT use a mixer on this dough! It's already a soft dough, so you don't need to and a mixer will only make the dough softer- too soft to roll in the cinnamon sugar.

text:
These cookies never let me down,  however I change up the recipe to fit my husband's likes.  First  I don't use shorting just another half cup of butter. 2. I double the vanilla. 3. I don't use cream of tartar  or baking soda instead I use 2 teaspoons baking powder. 4. I use one egg and one egg yolk 5. I bake at 350 for  10 minutes.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've never made a snickerdoodle before, and these didn't really come out looking like the pictures - however, they were really tasty and they likely didn't come out because I messed with the recipe. I realized as I was getting into mixing up my butter and shortening that I didn't really have enough white sugar, so I subbed icing sugar in because I had an abundance. As a result I ended up with a cookie ball that was a bit cake-like but it never flattened out. The flavor was fine but the texture would probably cheese off some connoisseurs. I also added a touch of nutmeg to the batter because I like nutmeg (hey I already messed with the recipe once, couldn't stop there) and I did some with cinnamon sugar on the outside and some with cocoa sugar on the outside. When I left it the full 10 minutes of baking it actually cracked open the tops a touch and gave them a pretty neat appearance. Next time I'll try to follow the recipe more directly though, see if they turn out as they should more.

I have always avoided Snickerdoodles because I never have shortening but I finally bought some (butter flavor) and got to try them. So glad I did, they were wonderful! The only changes I made was to switch the cream of tartar with white vinegar (same amount) and increase the sugar and cinnamon for the coating. I did also reduce the oven temp by 5 degrees and baked them for 9 minutes (on parchment so they could slide right off my pan and onto wire cooling racks). Very fun to make and delicious!

Display Name:
Sheri

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674149.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I’ve never made snickerdoodles before.  I read through the reviews so I was prepared.  I followed the recipe as listed apart from using lemon juice in place of cream of tartar.  The dough was too sticky to roll.  Still tried baking just one cookie for 8 minutes (as I had seen in other reviews) to see what happened.  It flattened out but was still crisp on the edges and soft and chewy in the middle.  Added 1/8 cup of flour.  Figure that lemon juice was additional liquid and may have added to the stickiness.  Decided to refrigerate the dough for 45 minutes which made it a little less sticky.  Didn’t make that much of a difference as far as the cookies getting flat.  Rolled the rest of the dough and put it in the cinnamon/sugar mixture.  Then I refrigerated the individual dough balls on a tray.  The dough cooled much faster, was nice and firm, and yielded a much better cookie.  I baked them for exactly 8 minutes, then immediately moved them to a cooling rack.  Cookies weren’t nearly as flat, and were delicious.  Taking them to a party tonight!  I’m sure they’ll be a big hit!  I’ll definitely make them again.

text:
So good! I let the eggs and butter sit out until they were room temperature. I mixed everything by hand and mixed the wet ingredients until most of the lumps were gone (2-3 minutes maybe). Added a bit more sugar - about a tablespoon more. I just used a bowl and plunked the balls in and rolled them, they weren't too sticky in my opinion. I baked them for 4 minutes, turned the pan and baked for 5 more minutes. I find with my oven that cookies turn out better when I turn the pan. I let the first batch sit on the pan for maybe a minute, second batch I got impatient and they went onto a cooling rack right away. They didn't fall apart for me but I had to be gentle. Definitely a keeper!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674146.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Perfect snickerdoodle recipe. Make sure your eggs and butter are room temp. I took them both out of the fridge and left them out over night before I made the cookies in the morning. Using my kitchenaid stand mixer, I combined all the dry ingredients together in a separate bowl and slowly added the dry mixture to the wet mixture, making sure it was combined before adding more dry mixture. I used a #20 disher to scoop the dough and only placed 6 cookies on a sheet at a time. I have silpat mats, so I used those. Since I made the cookies larger, I baked them for 10 min. After I took them out of the oven, I left them on the tray for 1 min before transferring to a cooling rack. They turned out perfectly and made 19 cookies.

country:
None
text:
These are delicious - one of my favorite cookies. This is exactly like another recipe on here (Snickerdoodles I) except that the other recipe uses all shortening instead of half butter and half shortening. I've made both, and there is not a notable difference. The all shortening ones may be SLIGHTLY whiter and SLIGHTLY better texture, but the difference is so negligible that you could definitely use either. I don't love shortening because it is so unhealthy, so using half butter works fine to make it a little more natural.

The new baker Sarah

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674149.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Alright so I'm kinda a beginner at best with baking. But the idea of snickerdoodles had me excited about trying to make a batch. First batch... me and everything in the kitchen was covered in dough ??. So I got back on and tried again. This time I literally heated the shortening to make it more blended ( I was mixing by spoon not mixer) and I added exactly 1 extra teaspoon of vanilla extract. Once I had it all blended I put the dough into the fridge for half a hour. It firmed up nicely but not hard. So using a ice cream scooper I made my balls to roll around the sugar and cinnamon mixture. Then I cut the ball in half and re rounded the half ball with my hand coated in the sugar and cinnamon for a even coating. Once shaped and placed on my tray I put it in at 400 degrees for exactly 9 minutes.( I had 3 trays total loaded but was only baking one at a time) . Using my plastic  spatula I gently moved the hot cookies to the wire cooling wrack. I had the next batch in and timer set each time between unload. The timing was pretty for letting them cool and transfer to a plate each time. Then the moment of truth.. I tried one and it was perfect! Firm on the outside not hard and soft melts in your mouth center. My spouse took a few to work and had co workers left and right begging for the recipe! I was able to make 20 cookies total and had I cut the balls into thirds I still think they would come out great and sizable. This was a pleasure to make and I think I could make them all day b

These are AMAZING! My kids and I loved these and they came out perfectly. I had to use Blue Bonnet Light and Ener-G egg replacer due to food allergies. I also used  the butter shortening rather than regular shortening just because that's what I had. userID:
6310408
Display Name:
msbelle21
isPro:

69

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674151.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've never liked making snickerdoodles as I don't necessarily care for the taste, but I must say that these are pretty delicious. I made half a batch as I was testing the recipe. I'm not a fan of shortening, so I used all unsalted butter. That was the only substitution I made to the recipe. I like soft cookies, so I baked them at 375 for 8 minutes on cookie sheets lined with baking mats. They could've used another minute or two as they were too soft, although completely cooked through as I left them on the sheets for 5-10 minutes. Baking them at 400 for 8 minutes may also be a remedy. Either way, the taste is phenomenal, and everyone who's tried them has raved. I did find the dough to be a little sticky, so I put it in the fridge a short while before rolling them in the cinnamon sugar. I used 1.5T of sugar and 1.5t of cinnamon, and it was perfect. This recipe is a definite keeper. Thank you!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Scrumptious! Followed the rec as is until the end. This is a fluffy cookie dough and quite yummy even unbaked. I did refrigerate before rolling because I was finishing up baking some chocolate chip cookies, but then I kept it out in between batches and it rolled just fine. The only tweet I had to make was rolling the dough in a mixture of powdered sugar and cinnamon instead of granulated because I ran out. The cookies themselves are so good, just like my memories of childhood snickerdoodles. They puff up while baking and do flatten a bit after they cool but I found if I baked them an extra min they retained a little of the  rise. Either way they are exactly what I want in a snickerdoodle. Can't wait to try w granulated sugar

Absolutely divine. I have made these multiple times and have not been disappointed yet. I use a cookie scoop to get perfectly portioned cookies and drop them into a ziplock bag with the cinnamon sugar mixture. Toss a few times for the perfect coating. I set the timer for exactly 8 minutes,  and not a second longer. They may look slightly undercooked, but they'll be perfect upon cooling.

Will definitely make again!

text:
I made this exactly as the recipe calls for. I did however follow the advice of a couple of reviews. The first was to use room temp egg and butter. The second was to use baking powder instead of cream of tartar if you want a puffier cookie or you just don't have cream of tartar. It worked out great!!  One thing I think would have made my cookies better was to REALLY coat them in cinnamon & sugar. I was afraid to over coat, don't be afraid! This is one of the best cookies I have ever made.

text:
These cookies are great, but I don't like the cream of tartar after taste, and the 1st batch I made came out kind of flat even though all of the ingredients were brand new and I tested the cream of tartar and baking soda to make sure they weren't flat.   For the second batch I took out about a tablespoon of egg white, used 1 cup of butter instead of shortening, and substituted 2 teaspoons of baking powder for the cream of tartar and baking soda.  Cooked for about 8 minutes and they were awesome!   Nice and puffy and chewy with no after taste!

text:
This is the recipe my grandmother used for many years!  If you really want them to be crunchy outside and soft
Inside, be sure to refrigerate dough for at least an hour before baking. Know your oven too.
Mine were done in 9 minutes and when they are done they don't look quite done.
Leave them on the baking tray 2-3
Minutes and they will be perfect when transferred to the cooling racks!

text:
Without a doubt, this is the best recipe for Snickerdoodle Cookies I have ever made. Everyone gave it a two thumbs up!!!
Note: The key was to chill the dough and quickly form a 1 1/4" ball...(They won't rise if you handle them too much.) If you want a soft center, do NOT over bake them. Another hint is to be sure you bake them on a cool cookie tin. I have done quite a few snickerdoodles over years and this one is by far my favorite. Simply delicious!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4325569.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
After some tinkering over the 50 or so times I've made this recipe, I've finally got it perfect!
-Replace all the butter with plain Crisco vegetable shortening (not butter flavored).
-Increase vanilla extract by 1.5x, and add half a teaspoon cinnamon into the dough
-Chill the dough for a couple hours before scooping and baking,
-Bake until they're JUST set for the traditional soft snickerdoodle style
It's also VERY important that the cream of tartar and baking powder is super fresh!  Fantastic recipe, everyone I know loves them.
Review:

5

text:
Hallo!  
For the past few years, I had been making Betty Crocker's snickerdoodles for Christmas family gatherings.  This year, however, I wanted to try something different.  
I used this recipe, and it turned out nicely.  The reason why I gave this only four stars was because I probably overcooked them.  I was fooled by their pale colour and, not wanting to give anyone food poisoning, cooked them three minutes longer than suggested.  The flavor was fine, but the cookies on the top shelf were a bit crunchy.
Overall, lovely recipe!

text:
These are great snickerdoodles. They are soft and chewy in the middle and lightly crisp along the edges, just the way I like them.

Like many of the other reviewers, I made up more of the cinnamon/sugar mixture so I could coat the cookies really well. I also used all butter - no shortening.

Using parchment paper on the cooking sheet allows you to  slide the paper with all of the cookies right off the cookie sheet and onto the cooling rack. No damaged cookies!

text:
Perfect snickerdoodle recipe. I don't keep shortening in the house so I made it with either all butter or all margarine. I find I do have to chill the dough if I make it with margarine otherwise it's too messy to roll. I usually have to add extra flour, at least a 1/2 cup more but I just go until the dough is the right consistency. I make a variation with 3/4 cup semi-sweet chocolate chips, almond extract, and 1/4- to 1/2 cup blended glace cherries that everyone says is amazing.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a fantastic recipe. I would give it five stars because it is nearly perfect, but I did have to alert it slightly. After reading everyone's reviews about them coming out flat, I took note of how wet the dough was once everything was mixed together. It was way too wet so I think I ended up adding another half cup of flour nearly. 
I also only had about ¼ cup shortening on hand, so I replaced the other ¼ cup with refined coconut oil. 
I didn't have cream of tartar so I replaced it and the baking soda with baking powder.
The end product was AMAZING!!! Perfect size, shape, taste, texture, just perfect. I'll be adding a photo shortly.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Wow, this recipe did not disappoint!  The only tricky part for me was deciding how long to bake them. I followed one reviewer's advice about baking them only 8 minutes, and that turned out to be the best option - EVEN THOUGH they would not lift off the sheet in one piece when I tried to transfer them to the cooling rack right away. I left another batch in for 9 minutes, but they crisped up after cooling so they were not as melt-in-your-mouth chewy in the center like the "raw" 8-minute batch.  So in my case, with my oven, it's 8 minutes and leave them on the pan for a few minutes until they hold together. Hope this helps others!

country:
None
text:
This is my go to Snickerdoodle recipe.  I was also plagued by flat cookies until I started refrigerating the dough before baking.  Perfect, puffed up Snickerdoodles.  I chill the dough for about 30-45 minutes, then make the balls and roll them in the cinnamon sugar and then return them to the fridge while the oven is heating.  I just take out and bake a dozen at a time.  It's also helpful to have two cookie sheets you rotate so one can completely cool before it is used again.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
5 star cookies! However the recipe as written would get 4 stars. I'm not sure why the author is adding cream of tartar and baking soda instead of just baking powder. The two main uses of cream of tartar are to stabilize egg whites or to combine it with baking soda to create baking powder. So if your CoT is bad (it doesn't usually go bad but it's one of those things that sits in the cupboard for months or longer without use) skip it and use baking powder for a more reliable result.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2016-10-18T04:48:53.857

These are so delicious! I followed the recipe exactly, even made a trip to the store just for cream of tartar because it really does add that special something that just makes it a snickerdoodle. I only got 36 cookies out of mine, but I prefer them to be a little big larger, and they were only in the oven for 8 minutes. I've made this recipe multiple times for my family, and every time they never last more than 24 hours! I've even gotten my friends hooked! 
I use coconut oil instead of shortening and it just gives it this light coconutty flavor, and that nutty sweetness. It's amazing. Also, I let the batter sit in the fridge for about 45 minutes before rolling them in the sugar. It helps them stay nice and fluffy.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Fantastic Snickerdoodle recipe!! I made it exactly as written, adding the wet ingredients first, used a hand mixer with whipping paddles to get the wet ingredients creamy & fluffy. Then kept the paddles on to incorporate the dry ingredients. The dough came out smooth, I turned it out onto wax paper, rolled it up & let it chill in the fridge for an hour before making the dough balls and tossing in the cinnamon sugar. The dough was so smooth, not sticky at all and rolled out like silk. Pressed down each ball with a fork before placing in the oven, came out PERFECT!! I made larger cookies and still got 46 cookies out of this recipe! Awesome recipe! Will continue to use this from now on! Thanks for sharing!

text:
Snickerdoodles are my FAVORITE...and this recipe is fantastic to use as a guide.  The first time I followed the recipe exactly and was not thrilled with the outcome...edible, but not remarkable.  They were still puffy - not very crispy. (Three stars.) 
  I just made them again with a couple of changes - I used all butter - no shortening.  I also double the amount of sugar in the coating and tripled the cinnamon.  After rolling the cookies - I flattened them a bit with the bottom of a glass because I prefer a crispier cookie.   They were the best snickerdoodles ever!

The perfect snickerdoodle!  Made exactly as the recipe called for. Only small difference was that I slightly flattened the balls of dough a bit because my oven tends to burn easily. They were wonderful!  Took them out when they puffed up and cracked, but felt slightly firm to the touch and immediately removed them (parchment paper and all) to a marble cooling slab to rest. Crunchy edges with a firm yet still chewy center.  Will be keeping this one as my only snickerdoodle recipe from now on!  Thanks!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I can't even remember the last time I baked cookies (I'm a cook, not a baker), but the grandkids were coming to visit and a granny *has* to have cookies for her grandkids. This recipe was very easy to follow, and the cookies were a big hit--my granddaughter, who previously would only eat chocolate chip cookies, even told me these cookies were delicious! I made two changes: I used white whole-wheat flour instead of AP flour and turbinado sugar instead of white sugar. Because turbinado sugar crystals are larger than white sugar crystals, I ended up using 4 T of sugar with the 2 tsp of cinnamon to roll the cookies in. I followed another reviewer's advice to bake the cookies for 9 minutes exactly, and the cookies turned out wonderfully chewy and delicious. I will definitely make these again!

text:
This is a fantastic recipe!  I live at 8,200 feet in the Rockies so I have to always make changes.  I decrease the sugar by 2 tablespoons and increase the flour about oh 1/8 to 1/4 of a cup.  I will also add 2 tablespoons of water to keep it from being too dry.  These worked great up here at this alltitude.  Now here is the change I had to make because I was out of shortening.  I used coconut oil in place of it.  The conversion was like 4 to 3.  I used about 1/3 cup of coconut oil.  It does change the taste a smidgeon but my daughter didn't know I did it and she asked me if I had added oatmeal to them.  Just a little FYI.  She still is eating them great and the hubster loves them too.

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I didn't have shortening or cream of tartar. Found out that I could substitute. I made a batch for 2 dozen, not 4 dozen. 

So 1:1 shortening for butter, and it's very soft and the edges were still very nice and crispy. 

And since baking powder = baking soda + cream of tartar
I put in 1.5 tsp of baking powder to replace both ingredients.

Glad I read the other reviews to take it out even if it seemed like it was still gooey. It settled well on the rack. I also did 3T sugar and 1tsp cinnamon to coat in a plastic sandwich bag. Really great suggestions!

The only thing would be that mine are pretty darn sweet, so maybe next time I'll put a little more flour. Hopefully this doesn't become a regular thing or I'm going to get diabetes! Lol!

Perfect Snickerdoodle recipe! These turned out perfectly and the taste, oh the taste! I followed the recipe exactly except I used butter flavored shortening instead of regular shortening which I think added nicely to the recipe. Very easy recipe, baked with 3 kids under 9 and they all had a ball! They especially loved rolling the balls in the cinnamon/sugar mixture. We made ours very heaping spoonfulls so we would have good sized cookies and cooking them the full 10 minutes worked out perfect. If you are doing average sized cookies then the 8-9 minutes would probably be the right time.

Display Name:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I followed the recipe exactly and just didn't care for the taste of these. Despite adding a bit of additional baking soda, the cookies were flat. They were soft enough, but pretty much tasteless. I did check my baking soda to ensure it was fresh, so that wasn't an issue. Disappointed in these.

Update: I made these again at my husband's request. I once again added an additional 1/8 teaspoon of baking soda in an attempt to create a fluffier cookie. Something else that I noticed this time around was the importance of dropping small spoonfuls of dough onto the cookie sheets. I tend to make my cookies a bit larger (personal preference), but these cookies turn out a lot better if they are smaller. The instructions don't specify how large or small each spoonful of dough needs to be. If you're making these cookies too big, they are more likely to flatten out. Try adding the additional baking soda and dropping a small teaspoon size ball of dough for each cookie. They actually puffed up this time and looked more like a traditional cookie. The taste is still bland, but my husband likes them, so I'll probably make them again for him.
Review:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3654385.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Beautiful and scrumptious! Easy to make and always a crowd pleaser. I chilled my dough overnight and baked for 8 min. I got them off the cookie sheets and onto a cooling rack pretty quickly as well.  I posted a photo, so you can see how they came out  If you have trouble with cookies spreading, it's often the butter being too warm/soft. Other possibility is over-mixing...mix just until the dry ingredients are incorporated. It is ideal to whisk your eggs before adding to butter/sugar mixture and also whisk to sift the dry ingredients - that way you don't have to mix the batter so much to get it all to incorporate. Also, greasing the cookie sheet can cause spread.  Thoroughly chilling the dough helps minimize spreading as well. Hope these tips help! It's a great recipe!

text:
These cookies are a bit tricky for me. When you take them out of the oven, be sure to take them out aright after they begin cracking and let them set before you take them off the cookie sheet. They'll be soft and just a little crispy on the outside. If you wait until they brown, they will be crunchy like boxed cookies. Either way they're yummy!

Cook for 8 min. exactly!  Even if they look underdone take them out.  Otherwise they flatten and become "snickerdoodle crisps."  I substituted the same amount of coconut oil for the shortening being careful to add it to room temperature ingredients.

I first ran across these in _Farm Journal's Homemade Cookies_ about 40 years ago, and I'm so happy to see it here, where it won't get lost!  Family and friends gobble these up. I'm making a double batch today for Xmas giving.

In addition to the cinnamon, I use  1/2 tsp ginger, 1/4 tsp nutmeg, and 1/8 tsp cloves ( or 1 tsp pumpkin pie spice) for extra spicy cookies.

text:
Great cookies! Some good tips are to roll them in the sugar cinnamon mixture not sprinkle it over. Because you will only get cinnamon and not sugar. Another is not to bake them all the way. You want to leave them just a bit gooey so there not hard. Last but not lest leave them in a zip lock bag for an hour or two and they will get really soft.

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made these a couple times now, and they've turned out great every time.  I ran out of the sugar/cinnamon coating with only 75% of the cookies rolled, so I would increase this by 1.5 next time (3tbsp sugar and 3tspn cinnamon).  I learned from my mother that any dough that's over-mixed after adding the flour will be tough.  I mix everything in my Kitchenaid, but use the lowest setting, and turn it off while measuring out the flour, only mixing while actually adding the flour to the mixing bowl for short periods of time.  I am having issues with my oven controlling the temperature, so this last batch baked for 10-12 minutes at approximately 375°F, and I removed them immediately from the parchment paper to cooling racks... perfect!  Thank you for this favorite!

This was a simple easy recipe that gave FANTASTIC results! The only rule to follow is 8 MINUTES! Don't cook them a second more! I thought my oven may have been a bit different than others, but the cookies really do set on their own! Take them out after 8 minutes even if they look under done.

userID:
10210558
Display Name:
Stef Van Camp
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6060554.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great base recipe-- The final product does have a faint "cream of tartar" ish flavor to it... I made a few adjustments: butter flavored shortening (helps mask the flavor a little), added more vanilla (again, helps hide the CoT flavor), and since I used a convection oven to bake, I decreased the temperature to 390.  Cookies were perfect after 8 minutes, and I used foil baking sheets which I instantly transferred to my granite countertops as soon as the timer went off.  

I also found that I needed to increase the flour by nearly 1/2 a cup-- Cookies were crunchy on outside and chewy/moist in the center... I'll probably try these again with an additional 1/3 or so cup of flour, and cut the cream of tartar by at least half.  I've done this in other cookie recipes, and while it makes the cookie slightly more dense, I find that I enjoy it a lot more than having that slightly metallic flavor lingering in my mouth.  Great simple recipe though-- I consider myself a more advanced baker (and as such, I'm considerably more picky than any of my family/friends)... The cookies are still delicious, and disappeared quite rapidly when I brought them to work with me.  Definitely worth a try for a quick, tasty treat! (...and they're pretty, too!)

text:
This is the first attempt at Snickerdoodles. It was so easy  they turned out so good and buttery and chewy with a little crisp on the edges, so good with homemade hot chocolate. Delicious!! I used the butter flavored shortening instead of just shortening, the flavor was wonderful, creamy on the inside when fresh out of the oven. I also added four teaspoons  lemon juice for the cream of tartar.  I was afraid it would have a lemony flavor but it didn't! I also saw that another review said to not use my electric mixer so I hand creamed the sugar butter mixture. I also took them out at 8 minutes on the dot. I didn't have parchment paper, so I used aluminum foil to line my pans, I hate to clean up. ;.) Turned out great, I will be making these for Christmas! Thank you Becky for the new recipe!!!

userID:

Display Name:
Krista Zimm
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2880845.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used all butter and pumpkin pie spice. 
If you use all butter your cookie will not hold their shape as well. Fluffy cookes require the butter to whipped really well. What used to take an electric hand mixer 10 minutes takes my kitchen aid [set up with a New Metro Beater Blade] 5 minutes tops. I made a double batch in my 5quart classic mixer and they came out just as I like them. Crunchy shell, cloud like interior that turns chewy as you eat it. Mmm. I love these cookies and they are a holiday staple for me. I hope my couple tips help you out as well.

text:
These cookies came out perfect. I used 3 tbsp, tsp for the sugar and cinnamon and had the exact amount  I needed. I used an electric hand mixer to initially blend the ingredents, but swithced to using my hands in order to avoid over mixing the dough. 8 minutes was the right amount of time, even though they do not look done at this point. I used parchment paper and as soon as these babies came out of the oven, I slid the paper and cookies onto wire racks for cooling. So good! Next time I will probably make a double batch.

I've made these several times and everyone LOVES them!!!! I get requests for them often! I bake on a light cookie sheet, 375*, and pull out of the oven at 8 minutes. I can let them stay on the tray for a minute and then take off to cool. They turn out perfect every time. I always use fresh ingredients since several reviews said that's how to prevent them from going flat. Has anyone ever froze the dough? Any suggestions on how long to thaw or can you freeze them after the dough has been put into balls and straight to the oven from the freezer?

text:
I've made these a lot and they've turned out great every time. Like other reviewers have said, only bake for 8 minutes. I tried to substitute vinegar and baking powder once for cream of tartar when I ran out and the cookies really proofed up. They were hard the next day. 
Another time I accidentally used lemon extract instead of vanilla (grabbed the wrong bottle) so I rolled the cookies in plain sugar and added a lemon glaze once cooled. My family loved my "new"  lemon cookies.  I will be making these for years to come.

userID:
16297689
Display Name:
Haydee
isPro:

9
favoritesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5746270.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made these cookies because i had bought the commercial dough version of it and I felt in love with them.  I was very excited by choosing this recipe and it was quiet easy to make. The only change I made was using both 1/2 cup of butter instead of 1/2 cup of shortening. I baked them for 8 minutes at 400 degrees and came out a little uncooked in the middle so I added one minute to the other batches. When I did the 10 minutes on my last batch they came out kind of burnt. So don't  do 10 minutes. Between 8-9 is best at that degree level. The taste is decent but I think is missing something from the commercial counterpart. I checked on the ingredients from the brand I had and I did not have corn starch on this recipe neither "bleached" flour so either they are lying or I am still in love with the commercial brand. Whatever it is I would try baking them again. Maybe I will add more sugar to the mix next time. The flour was not too sweet for me, just average. But hey making mistakes is how we learn, right? It was easy to make, no problem with that.

text:
These are so simple and delicious. I make them a little larger (about 1/4 cup each) and bake them for about 12 minutes. They are just a little crispy on the edges but still soft and chewy in the center. These freeze well too. I don't roll them in cinnamon & sugar, but do form them into balls, freeze on a baking sheet and transfer to a plastic bag. I bake them nearly frozen, and roll them in cinnamon & sugar just prior to putting them in the oven.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've always heard of snickerdoodles but never tried it before until now. The recipe produces a very good batch of cookies! It's not too sweet...with just the right ratio of sugar to cinnamon coating. I did not mix too much after adding the flour as others have suggested. I don't have a cookie scooper so I weighed out the dough to 42g each (which got me 23 nice sized cookies)...and baked it for exactly 11 minutes. I let it cool for about 30 minutes before trying. There's a light crunch outside but nice and chewy inside. Very basic but also a little unique due to the tang. Will keep this recipe!

text:
YUMM!! This was a favorite. I only made 24 very good sized cookies and baked each 11 minutes and they were absolute perfection. I liked the ratio of sugar to cinnamon to roll them in, though more sugar would be nice too to give it a little sweeter taste a little more crunch, but really these are awesome as is. I did have to add about 3/4 a cup more flour too, mine were very wet and I knew they were going to spread too much, so I increased flour and refrigerated the dough between batches. Awesome recipe, will definitely use again soon.

This is the first snickerdoodle cookies I have ever made and I must say that they were a success.  They are extremely easy to make and quick! REALLY GOOD!!! these are great. i made then twice and they jut fill the kitchen with this wonderful smell (and fill ur mouth w/ a wonderful taste later on ) 
just please, for your own sake, dont think ur smarter than baking soda. the 2nd time i made it, well lets just say the baking soda wasnt coming out so i tipped it a bit and the spoon kina hit the box and POOF! baking soda delight. i took most of it out, and didnt think much abt it cuz the dough tasted fine (i eat raw dough :P) BUT THEN....lo and behold. it came out of the oven fresh, hot. i pick one up and its sooo good, then suddenly im like YUCK!! the middle/after taste is horrible. they stayed in the cookie jar for months and served as good pranks for ppl. my cousni actually liked them and finished his cookie. but yeah. these are great!

text:
My first time making snickerdoodles and they are perfect!  i was afraid when i took them out that they wouldn't be flat enough but they settled just fine.  Friends and family simply devour these cookies!!  I need to work on rolling them, because i think mine were a tad too cinnamony (but that can't possibly be the fault of the recipe as i didn't use their amounts) but even as they were the taste of the cookie more than covered for it.  I tried to take them out after 8 minutes exactly as some people said but they still seemed way to soft, i even put them in for extra time, but i had added another sheet of cookies in the middle of the cook time, so that must have let a fair amount of heat out.  I can't praise these cookies enough.  So simple to prepare and they can be made so quickly!  If you're behind schedule to a dinner party, bring these!  Easy to make, quickly baked, and utterly delicious.

text:
This is a great recipe! I've read that people aren't happy with the end results of how their cookie looks. What might help is to mix or sift the flour, tartar, soda and salt prior to adding to the mixture. This helps your cookies cook evenly and has the puffiness you might be looking for. For my sugar/cinnamon mixture I personally used 6tbs of sugar and 1tbs of cinnamon, this is just personal preference. Have fun with variations of this recipe, and thanks for sharing!!

Will look no further for a Snickerdoodle cookie recipe after using this one.  Easy and quick to make and absolutely delicious.  They were perfect for my taste (a little on the crispy side) after 9 minutes in my oven. city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'm terrible at baking, but I was able to make these successfully! I made only 6 at first (in case they bombed; then I wouldn't have to throw out so much). In cases like these, I'm glad for ground flax seeds, because how else would I get the equivalent of 1/4 egg?? (I just followed the proportion on the box of flax seeds for egg replacer in baking: in this case, 1/4 tsp ground flax seeds, and 3/4 tsp water).

I used light brown sugar instead of white, since I didn't have white. I baked them at 200C (392F), the highest that my convection/microwave oven will go. The cookies were too soft to be handled at 10 minutes, so I put them back in for 5 more minutes, and they came out crispy. I'll try a little less time next time and see if they'll come out chewy.

city:

None
country:
None
text:
These are pretty good. I did not use shortening, I just doubled the butter and they turned out okay. They did flatten out, but I don't mind that. They are not too sweet, which makes them a nice change from all the overly sweet cookies/candies. I'm taking them to a church party tonight and we'll see how they go over. As for a funny aftertaste, I haven't noticed one at all. It is important to bake them for ONLY 8 or 9 minutes tops. Then let them cool for a couple minutes on the sheet before removing them to cool. Store quickly so they don't get hard.

text:
These cookies are AMAZING!  I saved this recipe a couple of years ago and decided to make these for the first time on Mother's Day this year.  I have since made about 10 batches for different events (potlucks, birthdays, Tuesdays, etc.), and everyone absolutely LOVES them.  The only thing I change is add extra sugar to the cinnamon/sugar mixture at the end.  No biggie, personal taste is all.  Make sure your baking soda and butter are both fresh, and pour off a little egg white to make them extra puffy (old school trick).  Thank you so much!!

text:
Soooooooooo good!  Addictive!   For me, they were the PERFECT consistency, exactly as described--crispy on the outside and chewy on the inside.  I added a bag of cinnamon chips to the recipe and should have compensated for the extra sugar by cutting back on the amount I put in.  Next time I will use 1/2 cup less.  Also, I added some fresh grated nutmeg.  Next time I will do that as well.  One last thought:  Next time I will add the cinnamon to the dough and use different colored sugars only to roll them in before baking to give them a more festive look!  I can color code them green and gold for our favorite team!  GREAT RECIPE!  Thank you so much for sharing!

country:
None
text:
Oh my, these were extraordinarily good!  I didn't have trouble with flattening & I simply mixed the wet ingredients first (partially melted butter in microwave) then added the salt, soda & cream of tartar, then mixed thoroughly.  Added flour last, mixing until no dry flour could be seen.  Formed balls, then rolled in sugar / cinnamon mix & baked for 8 minutes.  Adorable to look at, crisp on the outside, moist & chewy on the outside...very easy and enjoyable cookie...two thumbs up!!!

text:
Wow, these cookies were amazing. I made this recipe exactly according to directions except for doubling the butter and omitting the shortening. They are nothing short of perfection!! The only difficulty I had was cooking them for just the right amount of time...so keep a close on on them while baking. I read the most positive and least positive reviews before making this recipe, and the consistent "bitter, cream of tartar" as well as the "too sticky dough" reviews made me nervous. Fortunately, I did not have either of those problems WHATSOEVER...not even close. Thank you for an amazing recipe. I think my husband might love me a little more when he has these after work today :)

country:
None
text:
I think there is no need for that much cinnamon! It is more like two tablespoons of sugar to 1/2 teaspoon of cinnamon mixed together to make a balanced topping. Otherwise, the cinnamon overpowers the whole cookie. I find them best undercooked by at least a minute (so 7 minutes) because they will still bake a little on the pan and come out more chewy that way.

userID:

Display Name:
kms0321

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614260.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Best snickerdoodle recipe! I followed the recipe exactly, except I added a dash of cinnamon to the dough. First I mixed the butter, shortening, eggs, and vanilla. In anothet bowl I mixed all the dry ingridients, after that I mixed both. The dough was not sticky at all as other reviews, it came out perfectly. And I also chilled it for about 15 minutes. For the extra sugar and cinnamon I used about 4 teaspoons for each. I used a tiny bowl instead of the ziplock others were recommending. I also let them in the oven for exactly 10 minutes and the came out perfectly. They were chewy, bronzed, and not flat. If you have problems with this you should check the expiration date of the backing soda and that the creme of tartar is fresh. I recommend this recipe to everyone!

country:
None
text:
A waste of 1/2 lb. butter. Rushing to make Christmas cookies, I couldn't find my old Snickerdoodle recipe so used this one, and my entire two trays of cookies came out as two giant, flat cookies.
This recipe fails to remind the baker to CHILL THE DOUGH before baking. I should've known better, but just followed the directions and wasted an hour of my life and all the ingredients. 
I've checked other recipes on the 'net, and so far, they tell the user to CHILL the dough first. Careless directions, but I'll give myself a smack on the forehead too, for not noticing the missing instruction.
Of course, this didn't stop my husband an me from eating the giant cookies over the next couple of days, just tearing off strips of cookie, so it's not a 100% failure. Just nothing I can include in gift boxes for Christmas.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
My daughter and I made these tonight ... we experimented and tried the conventional oven and regular.   If you like more dark somewhat burnt cookies, then go the conventional route.   If you enjoy cookies that taste moist and soft, Do Not use the conventional oven, go the reg oven route.  Same time, same size for both and much different cookies, not that there is anything wrong with that.  

I do recommend chilling the cookie dough before you roll them into balls to bake.

The more cinnamon you add the darker they are, which can make them look burnt ... I added a little more sugar, not that there is anything wrong with that.

country:
None
text:
These cookies were a HUGE success in my Family's house- Super Delish! The only problem was that I didn't have eggs, or white flour. I was heartbroken that I couldn't try this obviously fantastic recipe... When I decided to look up egg substitutes. I found that powdered creamer will substitute for the egg's additive "hold together" and " fluffy" ness. I found some whole wheat flour in the pantry. =) I would've given these five stars, but under the circumstances, I haven't quite given these a fair trial. You can bet I'll try them again soon, with the proper ingredients. =) I also found that a decrease in temp helps with the after-texture of the cookies. Thanks for this awesome creation!

text:
Yum! I decided I wanted to make cookies at 2am while home from college, and this was the recipe I decided on, because we had no chocolate chips, and my school's snickerdoodles are gross =P Well anyways, I should have halved this recipe, because it makes a ton! I made 2 dozen of the cookies (one 12-sheet at a time) and decided to ball, dip, and freeze the rest because there was only 2 other people awake at the time! But these are really good, we keep cream of tartar on hand just to make snickerdoodles. I also needed more of the cinnamon-sugar to dip in. While some reviewers  said bake exactly 8 minutes, that was a little underdone for the second batch, the first batch where I pulled them out when the tops had been cracked for a minute or so was the best, but I forgot to time it.

userID:
1464925
Display Name:
Breanne Baird
isPro:

followersCount:
2

0

10
favoritesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4234138.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a super fantastic Snickerdoodle Cookie. I only had extra large eggs so I added half of the yolk & all the the egg white of the second egg. I didn't over mix the batter. I used the flour that I had in the freezer.  I did not let it sit out but the cookies turned out great. They were not flat. I think the trick is to make sure you don't flatten them. The ones that were more round stayed fluffier. I used old cream of tarter & baking soda & didn't have a problem. The ones that I made smaller turned out fluffier. I also used my hands to form the balls & I noticed that the sugar & cinnamon would get inside the dough a bit & I think it made it more yummy! So play with them & enjoy, we sure did!
Review:

5

text:
I just made this recipe tonight. It is very good. I would suggest cooking on 400 for at least 9 minutes. I  followed some of the reviewers advice to cook only for 8 minutes on 375 and they were not done and fell flat. I cooked the second batch longer at 400 and they are perfect. I guest everything depends on your oven. I have a convection oven so they turned out very even. Thank you for sharing the recipe.

userID:
7524245
Display Name:
Jessica Salmans
isPro:
False
followersCount:
14
followingCount:

2
favoritesCount:
10
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2454021.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made these last night and they were AWESOME!!!  The dough turned out perfectly (not sticky at all) and I used a 1TBS measuring scoop to scoop up the dough and keep my cookies uniform.  Using that method, I got 40 gorgeous cookies.  I agree with the other reviewers that baking them for EXACTLY 8 MINUTES and then removing from the oven was best.  My cookies were thick, chewy, and delicious.  I like a lot of cinnamon, so I upped the ratio of cinn to sugar before rolling them. I did use the shake in a ziplock bag trick instead of rolling them by hand. For people who said their dough was too sticky, I suspect the culprit is one of two things:  either your butter was MELTY and not just soft OR your dough got too warm after sitting out.  I recommend putting your dough in the fridge between baking batches to keep it cool.

Made these awesome cookies for father's day with my daughter. Used all margarine, instead of butter and shortening; mixed by hand; added 1/4c extra flour to make the dough easier to roll into balls; 8 minutes exactly and transferred immediately to cooling sheet; 3 tbsp sugar and 3 tsp cinnamon. They turned out PERFECTLY! And the recipe was super easy! Thanks for the great cookies!

text:
I loved these snickerdoodles! I've never made this type of cookie before but I do love eating them, so I thought I should give it a shot.  These are simple to do and the results are addictive. I didn't have cream of tartar (I never do) so I just used lemon juice (2 tsp. for every 1 tsp of cream of tartar) and that worked very well.  The process of coating the dough in the cinnamon sugar becomes much easier (and less messy) when you just put the mix in a baggie and drop the dough balls in 1 at a time.  Enjoy :)

text:
These cookies were SO good! There is ust something to keep in mind when baking these: DO NOT take them out earlier. They were meant to be baked for a fixed period of time, any time shorter than the recommended time will leave your cookies too soft and possibly undercooked. If you follow the directions as written, your cookies will turn out just fine. They were definitey a crowd pleaser

First time making these kind of cookies and they turned out perfect! Tip for baking; I separate dough into 4 and flour hands and work each 1/4 into 12-14inch log on mat, then divide into 16 with knife. Much easier than trying to scoop . . . Also decided to roll a few in powdered sugar and they were yummy too!

I decided to bake cookies this year as part of my holiday gift to friends and coworkers.  I was astounded by all the wonderful reviews and decided 'What's a cookie platter without snickerdoodles!!' and made these last.  I threw on my headphones, turned on the mp3 player, and had a blast dancing and making these.  I followed the recipe exactly as written, but had to use margerine sticks instead of butter, since I ran out, and used vegetable shortening.  My mother smelled them in the oven and knew what they were without even seeing them.  They smelled so delicious!  I immediately tried one out of the oven and they were perfect.  Everyone who had a chance to try one said they were the best they had ever had!!  Thanks Mrs Sigg for these amazingly yummy cookies :D

text:
I made these for Christmas this year, and I kind of wish that I had never found this recipe because they are delicious and I've eaten many of them over the past few days! I've baked quite a few batches, but on my most recent one, I omitted the shortening and used 1 full cup of butter. I also used only about 1.5 tsp of cream of tartar. I think that was my best batch so far. It's hard to stop eating these cookies so please BEWARE when making this recipe...or make sure you have lots of people to share these cookies with so you won't eat them all!

text:
These yummy cookies come out perfect for me everytime, regardless of age of baking soda or cream of tartar.  Just used these two ingredients that were a year old and cookies still came out perfect. I bake at 400 for exactly 8 min take out of oven and whether I remove immediately from cookie sheet or let rest before removing makes no difference.  I use small cookie scoop that makes 1 in balls and makes 45 cookies.  They flatten out some but not too much.  Like I said, perfect everytime!!  Very easy to make. I do increase the sug/cinn mixture to the 3T/3t and that's just enough.

text:
Delicious ginger cookie.  I replaced the water the orange juice as another reviewer suggested, but I wish I added the zest of the orange, too.  I also agree with another review that you MUST wait before you roll these cookies.  I would call them a 2-day cookie or refrigerator cookies, b/c you really need to let them set up first before you can roll them.  Instead I'm waiting around cooking 24 at a time while I wait to roll the others.  (I doubled the batch!)  Good otherwise!

This is the exact same recipe as in an old Betty Crocker cookbook I've used for years.  These always turn out great. Sometimes I chill the dough before forming into balls "the size of small walnuts" as the cookbook recipe states.  This make the dough easier to handle. city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
just remade these today. had to sub the cream of tarter with baking powder, no baking soda, and used coconut oil instead of shortening- did not have any. they came out soft and fluffier than thinner traditional cookies. which I like myself. at 390 and 8 mins they were almost perfect. went up to 400 2nd batch, but since those were smaller cookies, a little too brown I think on bottom. so shoulda left it at 390. bigger cookies needed about 30 seconds longer.(foil cookie sheets fyi) I didnt get that "cracked" top with cinnamon on top look- but i pressed in red and green sugar sprinkles for christmas, tried baggie method for rolling- end up easier to chill dough,make the balls , in large bowl, then sprinkle tops.parchment sheets so easy- slid whole sheet to cool. they dont look quite the same as some others, but they look good to us, nice and soft, crispy edge- tasted Wonderful! might add little more cinnamon to tops next time, but our fav either way- much better than "xmas  cookie cutouts". thanks so much for recipe!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674145.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Mix the dry ingredients seperately. If blend the wet ingredients well before you add the dry ingredients, it makes the dough fluffier and adding about a half (1/2) cup of milk makes them fluffier too. Oh, also spraying the cookie sheets with pam helps them from sticking to the pan and, if you have an electric oven, it also helps them not get as crispy. Oh, and I used 2 Tbls. of sugar to 1 1/2 tsp. of sugar.

text:
This is a great cookie.  I like the addition of vanilla to Betty Crockers' recipe. but I only use 1 teaspoon.  I like Betty Crockers' instructions to "mix" where these instructions say to "cream".  I know it's probably a small thing but creaming is a "method" that can lead someone down a road they really don't want to go down.

text:
absolutely amazing. i didnt realize the first time it called for shortener and i saw another review saying to replace with butter, so i did that. the only issue is when i tried to roll it i couldnt. they were waaay too sticky. i melted the butter so im not sure if that was the reason or not. i had to use a spoon and just drop the dough into the sugar/ cinnamon mix and just shake it around and plop it onto the cookie sheet. they didnt look to pretty going into the oven so i told my husband we may be eating ugly cookies. haha. when i pulled them out though they were beautifully spread out and puffy. i cooked them for 8 minutes but it wasnt long enough so i cooked for 3 more minutes and let them sit. delicious! crispy and soft and chewy. my husband was even surprised at how soft they were. i cant get over how amazing they are :) thank you for this recipe and next time i will def try to jsut soften the butter and not melt it hopefully that helps. i added extra flour, not sure how much but like 2 or 3 tablesppons. and i also did wet my hands and even added flour on my hands but still the dough was too sticky. oh well they tasted and looked delicious!

text:
I had these cookies at a soccer game and just had to get the recipe. When my friend sent it to me I knew I had to make them right away! I read a lot of reviews before making them. I didn't have enough cream of tatar so I used what I had (a little less than 1tsp) and then 1tsp of vinegar. I made them a little small. I prefer smaller cookies! I baked them for 8 min. and they came out perfectly! They stayed "puffy" and taste awesome. It made 75 cookies. I measured them and they are 2". I use my "stone" to bake them and they really cook well on it. I did cook one stone for about 10 min. because I really like crispy cookies and omg they came out delicious. It just depends on your personal taste preference. ENJOY!

text:
Many thanks for all the input on creating the perfect snickerdoodles.  I took all comments into account and made my changes as such... I added 1 teas of cinnamon (Siagon, which in my opinion is excellent), to the dry mixture, 2 teas baking soda and 1 teas cream of tarter.  I baked my first batch for 8 mins, then the second batch for 9 mins.  I preferred my cookies at the 9 mins of baking time.  I baked the cookies on a "rim-less" cookie sheet lined with parchment paper, and successfully slid the parchment, with warm cookies still on, onto my stone counter top.  Perfect, every time.  Oh, I also made extra sugar topping and was really generous with that part.  Enjoy!!!

userID:

Display Name:
lnhbp

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614247.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I halved this recipe. I used all margarine in place of butter and shortening. I softened the butter a bit before creaming with sugar, eggs, and vanilla. I then put flour, cream of tartar, baking soda, and salt in the same bowl. It was very convenient. I then refrigerated the batter while I mixed the cinnamon and sugar in a ziploc bag. It took quite awhile to get the right mixture because I didn't measure. After refrigerating the batter for about 10 minutes, I took it out. I rolled them into balls and put them in the ziploc and rolled it. I heated the oven to 375 degrees and baked the cookies for 9 minutes. In the end, I got 12 good sized cookies. They came right off my ungreased pan. They were crispy on the outside and soft on the inside. Not too sweet either. Love them!
Review:
Rating:
5

text:
Delicious!!! I use to make snickerdoodles with my dad all the time when I was younger & I can't find my recipe anywhere. This was such a great recipe! I didn't have any cream of tarter so I took someones advice on using lemon juice instead & it turned out great! Also as other reviewers mentioned they only need to be cooked for 8 min. only & taken out immediately even if they seem raw.....that keeps them soft & gooey in the middle just the way I like them!! My only minor problem was that when I opened my oven it was very smokey & set off the fire alarms......maybe the sugar/cinnamon mixture burning a bit on the bottom of the cookies?? Other than that little problem they tasted great!!!! I can't wait to make these fun cookies with my son when he gets a little older!!!

I've never had homemade snickerdoodles before and this was such an easy recipe! They turned out great! I didn't have any shortening and didn't feel like running out to the store, so I used lard instead. I used just a little less than the 1/2 cup called for because lard has a stronger flavor, you can't taste the lard at all. I will definitely be making these cookies over and over.

Thank you for posting this great recipe

text:
I loved this! They came out exactly as I expected. And I'm glad they look super appetizing!  If you use a normal size egg, I'd still recommend you to pour out a really small amount of egg white, to avoid it spreading out.   Also, when rolling the dough, dont overdo it! The dough is sensitive, and you want to keep it soft. So be careful and gentle. It's fun!  When baking them, put them on 375 degrees and for 9 minutes exactly. When out, pull them off the sheet by dragging the parchment paper onto a wirerack and wait for them to cool off! PERFECTiON!

My co-workers and husband ate it up like nothing!  8 min is perfect!  Before popping into oven, I added a little pinch of the cinnamon sugar on top of dough and came out with perfect sugar!
(Edit: The second time around, I used applesauce instead of butter to cut down on calories.  The Snickerdoodles came out fluffly and soft, still delicious.  Mix may be a little runny if you use applesauce, so just put in fridge/freezer to help harden the mix a little bit)

None
country:
None
text:
This is a great recipe for the perfect snickerdoodle. I initially baked them according to recipe, and they provided a nice crunchy cookie, but I really prefer a chewier cookie. On the rest of my batches, I lowered the temp to 375 and took them out after about 7-71/2 minutes. I needed them to stay soft for a while so I could give them away in treat tins. They were perfect, and lasted for several days. They were soft, while still having a nice crunch around the edges. Also, I subbed lemon juice fro cream of tartar because I don't care for it.

text:
Just baked these this afternoon to bring in to work - I work in a cancer hospital pharmacy and shared the cookies with the doctors and nurses. Trust me, once they have a good cookie, word spreads. They were gone within an hour and I even had some overnight nurses disappointed that they missed out. I followed the recipe exactly except I followed the idea to toss the cookie dough balls in a bag of sugar/cinnamon mixture and baked at 375 for 8 min EXACT (1 min later and they started to burn). So easy to make! Thank you!

text:
This recipe really is fantastic!  I didn't have shortening on hand, so I substituted butter.  I also didn't have cream of tartar, so I substituted 4 teaspoons of baking powder and left out the baking soda.  I baked them for 7 minutes.  They were perfect!  I can't say if they were any better than the original recipe because I haven't made it that way yet, but if you're in a bind and don't have those ingredients on hand, these subs still turned out 5 star cookies!

I realize this recipe probably does NOT need one more review, I had to add my praise for a perfect snickerdoodle recipe. I have tried many, but this is the best - probably because of the mix of butter and shortening. I should also add that I creamed the butter/shortening and sugar for a long time, probably 3-5 minutes. My husband loves them, and he is a cookie connisseur.
