text:
These cookies are wonderful. I carefully read other members reviews and the only change I made was added 1 teas. baking powder along with the baking soda and cream of tarter. They came out fluffy and soft. Very yummy! ***UPDATE** I made these again and due to diet changes I only have margarine in the house, I didn't think it would make much of a difference, boy I was wrong! It is VERY VERY important that you use only butter, no substitutes. Margarine turned them flat and crispy, despite that I use fresh baking powder & baking soda. Using butter keeps them soft & round.

text:
These were good and simple to make. Used all margarine because that's all I had. Used more sugar and cinnamon and took the very helpful advice of putting it in a sandwich bag to roll the balls in. I'm not a big fan of the cream of tartar taste in it so will definitely sub lemon juice. It wasn't flat, dry, or crunchy at all. The only thing that bothered me was that I couldn't get it to crackle. 12/4/10 - Just finished making 30 dozen of these... and lived! I used butter flavored crisco and vinegar to replace the cream of tartar. Loved it this way! I also chilled the dough this time, which I think helped with the puffiness. Changed rating from 4 to 5 stars.

text:
Perfectly perfect! This is similar to my keeper recipe, but it ties! I used 1/4c. more flour because I live in high altitute (CO). My first tray was puffy and a bit on the smal side, so with the same sized dough balls I gently patted the second tray down with the flat part of a knife. This tray turned out more like the featured picture. I will use this method for this recipe again. Thank you!

None
text:
Really good! I only did three things differently. I left out the salt, and instead of butter, used all shortening. I also read it was better to use your hands for this, but I used the paddle attachment of my Kitchenaid. Once it was blended, I took it out and shaped it. I made the coating in a small bowl that I rolled the balls of dough around in. I baked it at 400 for exactly eight minutes. They were VERY puffed up and fragile, but hardened as they cooled.   Just the right texture of chewy, and not sickeningly sweet. My husband LOVED them, and he doesn't normally like cinnamon. So good!

country:
None
text:
UPDATE: ALTHOUGH STILL YUMMY DAYS LATER, I THINK THESE ARE BEST FRESH OUT OF THE OVEN ("NOTHING" COMAPRES IMHO). I EVEN TRIED SPRITZING WITH H2O BEFORE REHEATING IN THE MICROWAVE AS ONE REVIEWER SUGGESTED.... Oooh! These are SOOOOO good!!! Made A 1/2 batch for my bf & I. B/c I used my 3 T PC scoop, I only had enough dough for 12 cookies (as opposed to 24 sm. ones). I pretty much followed Beth's directions exactly, except for the following: a) I added 1/2 c. of Hershey's mini cinnamon chips to my dough (I was trying to duplicate Noodles & Company's snickerdoodles which have cinnamon chip "chunks" in them), b) I upped the cinnamon-sugar mix. to 2 T sugar / 2 t cinnamon and, for ease, comb. both in a lg. Ziplock bag & gently dipped ea. "formed" cookie ball into the mix. (note: I did not shake as others have advised against doing so...), & c) baked my cookies on parchment lined baking sheets for 11 min. The finished cookies were crispy around the edges & soft in the center. One note: I suggest (as some others have also) to dip only the tops of your cookie dough into the cinn.-sugar mix. My oven was smoking (fire extinguisher please...) b/c the bottoms of some of my cookies were burning! I noticed just in the nick of time, so I was able to salvage all but a few of them. Beth, you've done it again! These are incredible, and, by far the best cookie I've ever made. You ARE the cookie queen (hehe!) :)

userID:
3499651
Display Name:
Kiki
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614261.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Ohh these were absolutely delicious! I simply could not keep out of them!! No they do not come out puffy but I like them in their original shape so I can taste more of the outer coating. :) My favorite part of these cookies is they way they spread in the oven. usually I am very OCD about rolling balls of cookies; with many recipes it is so easy to get inconsistent cookies that differ in size and shape, but these all came out in perfect circles! Sooo great! They were crispy at the edges and chewy in the middle the day I baked them, but even when I tightly plastic wrapped them, they lost crispiness the next day. They became chewy, but I guess that's better than lots of cookies that become rock hard the next day right? Also, I had to take an intermission and left coated, rolled cookie dough balls for a hour. When I came back and recoated them, they baked to have much bigger cracks than the ones I bake right away.. I thought it looked a lot nicer. Not sure how this works but hope it helps! By the way, whisk the dry ingredients besides the sugar in a separate bowl. In a bigger bowl, cream the shortening, butter, and sugar by hand for about 2-3 minutes until it's pale yellow, but not fluffy. Then add the other wet ingredients, mix, add the dry ingredients... mix until blended. Don't overmix or else it becomes cakey. The creaming part is crucial for the chewiness and texture of the cookie. Do NOT be afraid to overcoat these, they never come out too sweet!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Wow, yum! I forgot how much I love snickerdoodles. After reading the reviews, I upped the topping to 3 T and 3.5 tsp (and put it in a plastic baggie), I also set my oven to slightly less than 400 because my oven tends to be pretty hot. I hand-mixed everything, and kept the dough in the fridge while I cleaned everything up and pre-heated the oven in hopes that the cookies wouldn't spread out too much while they baked. I took them out when they were cracked but still lightly wet-looking in the cracks, which was around 7ish minutes for me. They turned out great! The texture is awesome and the flavor couldn't be better. We'll see if there are any left by the time my boyfriend gets in town tomorrow, ha!

text:
I give this 5 stars -- used more sugar/cinnamon mix for the whole batch.  Made mine larger (increase your baking time; watch carefully).  These freeze very well in an airtight container.  I prefer storing mine in my Lock & Lock brand.  As a quick reminder to beginner bakers:  Grease your hands with a little vegetable shortening when rolling the balls (goes much easier/faster).

text:
i changed a lot of things so this isnt really a very fair review. i saw that a lot of people were complaining about flat cookies so i decided to  half a teaspoon of baking powder on top of the cream of tartar and baking soda. that was not the best decision ive ever made. they turned out more cakelike than i like my cookies. I also made them gluten free using brown rice flour, quinoa flour and bob's red mill Gluten free flour mix. Gluten free baking is always a little different. I also used 1 cup white and 1/2 cup brown sugar for the cookie dough instead of all white sugar. im pretty sure that was a good decision. next time i make these i wont try to change the recipe so much. very pretty cookies!

text:
Ugh, I screwed this one too...I'll post my mistake here so it's not repeated by anyone...do NOT use baking soda in place of baking powder...you'll get acidic cookies from the cream of tartar. I still think this has too much cream of tartar though, I would use half or do the lemon juice...I'm not a snickerdooddle fan( too boring of a cookie for me) but after sitting out for a day the acidic taste did die down and tasted better.

country:

text:
Let me start by saying I usually only rate a recipe if I am giving it 5 stars, however considering this recipes great ratings I just had to review it.  My son LOVES snickerdoodles and although I am avid baker this is one cookie I just never tried to bake so I figured I'd give it a shot after seeing this one's  rave reviews.  I followed the recipe to the T with the exception of using all butter and not shortening because I rarely use shortening in my baking (butter just gives better flavor and better results and is healthier).  I had no problems with the dough and they baked up nicely after 9-10 minutes, not as puffy as I hoped, but good enough.  However all these taste like is a jazzed up sugar cookie. These do not tast like true snickerdoodles.  They are rather bland.  My son only ate 1 cookie and the rest have been sitting on the counter...this says alot b/c he usually will finish off a batch of cookies in two days. My husband likes them but not enough to request them again...I decided to give this 3 stars only because they did taste a little better the next day. If you're looking for a true snickerdoodle recipe that tastes like the ones you buy in a store or coffee shop, keep searching, I know I am.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These are GREAT! I get RAVES everytime I make them and plenty of requests for the recipe. I found it best to take the top rack out at 7 minutes and bottom out at 7 and a half since my stove is old and cooks a little hotter than what it's supposed to. Take them immediately off the pan. I've made several batches and I assure the easiest way to get these covered in cinnamon and sugar is to use a small ice cream scoop to dip some out of the bowl and onto a plate with the mixture then cover the top with the mixture and roll it around to get the best even coating without the dough sticking to your hands. Works great is a fun way to spend time with the kids!

If overmixed they still taste good but are flat and ugly.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I hadn't made Snickerdoodles in years, mainly because I remembered them as being just 'so-so', but let me tell you that THIS recipe will be made often at our house!

I followed the recipe exactly as written and...oh, my Goodness, they were outstanding!

The dough was a cinch to mix up.  I used my 1 1/4" cookie scoop and got exactly 70 cookies!

I'll admit that I didn't think the cinnamon-sugar amounts would be enough for all that dough, but after coating the entire doughballs, (even the bottoms), there was still about 1/2 teaspoon leftover, so I poured it into my shaker bottle of cinn.-sugar in the spice rack.

These baked on my insulated cookie sheets, (Air-Bake), to perfection in exactly 8 minutes.

As instructed in the recipe, be sure to immediately remove the cookies from the pans or they WILL stick!

Thanks, Beth, for a wonderful recipe that I'll be proud to include in my Christmas gift baskets!

Followed the recipe to the letter other than chilling the dough for an hour before rolling it, and used the bakers method for measuring baking ingredients by weight and not by volume. These turned out perfect. Thanks! I also found that it does indeed need only 8 mins and not a second more, then immediately cool. A side note to people reading reviews to consider. High Quality ingredients in, produces a better quality product, always.

text:
This is the best Snickerdoodle recipe there is. I can't stress enough, not to over bake them. No matter what you think they look like. 7 minutes is perfect they set up as they cool. The acrid taste I think the one reviewer commented on, that is the taste of cream of Tarter, it doesn't matter how fresh it is. One advantage I think that I have on these is I ONLY use a Vanilla paste instead of liquid vanilla. Once you taste the paste version, you will always have the upper hand in everything that you bake.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/142925.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Addictive.  Took these to work and they were gone in minutes. ALL OF THEM!  I followed the recipe except for I was out of vanilla, so I decided to use butter flavoring instead.  It just made them even more rich tasting.  I baked mine for 9 minutes.  I use a convection oven and placed three trays of cookies in at a time, thus, the extra minute was needed.  Just to experiment, I baked one batch for 10 minutes and they were perfect while warm, but after they cooled, they were crispy almost all the way through.  Still heavenly though!  I let my cookies cool on the cookie sheets, because this actually allows the cookies to maintain their chewiness.  All in all, I will use this as my default Snickerdoodle recipe in the future.

text:
great cookies, ive never made snickerdoodles before but these were fast and easy.  I used the suggestion of dipping rather then rolling in the cin/sug mixture and i had absolutely no trouble with cookies sticking to the pan. I added about an extra 1/4 flour because my dough was to sticky to handle  ...OH and for those of you who didnt have cream of tartar, lemon juice or vinegar like me :) i omitted the cream of tartar and baking soda and used 4 tsp of baking powder....the only difference is i have nice big fluffy cookies but i like them like that....very delicious i will be adding these to my gift cookies this year

text:
I have never made these before. If I didn't read everyone's reviews I would have been screwed. I'm on my fourth batch now. The first ones, I followed the above recipe perfectly. The second batch, I realized you can put Pam on the cookie sheet, (or else you will end up with 1/2 a cookie). I added 1/2 Cup more flour, scooped them with a cookie scooper and rolled them around with a tablespoon. Also, from reading reviews, I found out you really do need to take them out after 8 minutes, no matter what they look like.

text:
Made a batch of these for a small get-together with about a dozen guys. Maybe I made the cookies too small, but they made 5 dozen, not 4. That being said, at the end of the day there were only 8 or so left.
I personally liked them, but thought they were a little acrid, as mentioned, so I'll swap the amounts of baking soda and cream of tartar next time.
Also, I used about 4 times the amount of recommended cinnamon sugar coating. Just my personal preference.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Mine didn't spread out at all and were thick, crunchy cookies. I didn't chill the dough so was surprised that they didn't spread more. Tasted fine (no bitter aftertaste from the cream of tartar) but I wanted flat, chewy cookies. Next time I will press down with a glass before baking. Also, they were great fresh out of the oven but within minutes, they had hardened. 

Update: Changing my review to five stars! Baked another batch and made sure to flatten the dough balls and took them out of the oven even though they still looked wet on top. This yielded the perfect, chewy, flat cookie I've wanted!

text:
I hadn't made snickerdoodles since 7th grade home ec. I don't remember how those turned out, but these were chewy and pretty good. I upped the cinnamon/sugar mixture to 3 t cinnamon and 3 T sugar and then I used the ziploc method to completely coat the dough. I cooked them for exactly 8 minutes. On some batches, I immediately removed from the pan to cool and some I didn't remove until the next batch came out. It didn't seem to make a difference.

I love this recipe and I've been using it for years! Of course I've adapted it to make it my own over the years as well...

text:
Awesome recipe! Like other reviewers have stated, increase cinnamon to 3-4 teaspoons and white sugar to 3-4 tablespoons, and pour the two ingrediants into a sandwhich sized ziplock baggie. Drop the  ball of dough in and shake the baggie for the ball to get covered in cinnamon, and sugar. This method is mess-free.

Very good cookies. I did adjust the cooking time and oven temp.  I cooked them for 9 minutes at 350 then left them on the pan for 1 minute after taking them out of the oven.  They turned out perfectly - slightly crisp on the edges and chewy in the center.  I also used 3 Tablespoons sugar and 3 teaspoons cinnamon using the shake in bag method and I think 2 and 2 would have been plenty because I had a lot left over.

text:
The best thing about this recipe is that it is good as is - you do not need to make ANY modifications.  The reason they are so good is because of the shortening - I never used this recipe before because shortening is not an ingredient I usually keep in my pantry but I will now - it makes all the difference.  Use plenty of sugar/cinnamon for the coating.  Less time in the oven is better - they may look a little underdone but will firm as they cool.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have never made snickerdoodles before and someone requested these so I read through bunches of recipes and decided to try this one. I read through all the reviews. I cut the cream of tartar down to 1 1/2 tsp, used 1/4 cup shortening, 3/4 cup butter and used 2 tsps cinnamon and 3 tbls sugar for the coating. I put the dough in refrig for about 40 min. and I used my cookie scooper to make the balls. I have a convection oven and baked them at 390 for 9 minutes.  I think they came out pretty good. The real test will be if the person requesting them likes them.

text:
YUM!  My kids are Chocolate Chip Cookie addicts.  We made this recipe during a recent rainy day and they LOVED them, absolutely couldn't get enough!  Sigg's Snickerdoodle Sunday is a new tradition!  I baked them on parchment paper for 9 minutes and they were perfect, crispy around the edges and chewy in the middle.  The shortening makes them fluff up nice, just right!  I also mixed the cinnamon/sugar in a baggie, but then dumped the mixture on a paper plate and let the kids roll the dough in the mixture, it was perfect.  I ended up using alot more than the 2 T of each, I just mixed it to taste!

text:
These are great! I rolled them into about 1.5-2 inch balls, and dropped them in a baggie with the cinnamon sugar mixture.
I followed the recipe exactly except that I reduced oven temp to 390 and cooked exactly 8 minutes then removed immediately to wire rack. Result was a crunchy on the outside, soft and chewy on the inside cookie. So great.
I creamed the first ingredients (butter, shortening etc) with a mixer but then when I added the flour I mixed it by hand.
Got about 50 medium sized cookies out of this. Very easy and will make again in a hurry. Thanks

I made mini cookies, when cooked they were about the size of a 50 cent piece. My kids rolled them in the cinnamon/sugar mixture and placed them on the cookie sheets. I needed to shorten the cooking time so they didn't get to hard. I had to make a double batch just to have some to bring into work because the kids ate them as soon as they were cool enough.

  To make them soft again after fully cooling I put some in the microwave for about 15 seconds or so and they are just like when they came out of the oven.

I found this recipe to be very easy to follow, and the dough was ready to use immediately! I used a cookie dropper instead of rolling these into a ball. I also used the zipper bag suggestion - shaking the cookies in the bag with sugar and cinnamon. My only recommendation would be to flatten the cookies out a little before baking if you use a dropper - a few of mine were a little too puffy! Still turned out terrific, and taste just how I expected!

Made these last night. Baked them at 375 degrees as suggested. I like chewy, my husband likes crunchy, so to compromise I let half the batch bake a couple minutes longer than ther other. (I never go by recipe times because my oven is weird. I just have to "babysit".) These cookies are mainly for our church cookie social and to give as gifts, but the baker and spouse always have to "test" them. And the one I tried was chewy goodness, but just a little flaky around the edges. Not my favorite TYPE of cookie (I'm more of a chocolate or molasses fan), but I would definitely make these again. Husband said they are good for "dipping". :)

First time snickerdoodle attempt and these came out great.  Reading others' reveiws is always helpful and recommended when trying a recipe for the first time. I followed the recipe almost exactly, and used others' suggestions to cook for 8 minutes. Mine came out underdone- and my oven is always too hot! Maybe its because I used all butter. Other than that, these were great little cookies. My husband doesn't really eat sweets, and he says these are his favorite now! He calls them French Toast cookies, because he says that's what mine ended up tasting like! I will make these again and cook for probably 9 minutes.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These aren't the prettiest cookies, but they are certainly yummy.  I made it twice.  I followed the recipe exactly the first time. People liked it but wished there wasn't the cream of tartar aftertaste.  The second time, I replaced the cream of tartar with 2 teaspoon of fresh lemon juice, and the cookie turned out great with no funny after taste.  The lemon juice does not affect the texture of the cookie at all.  Aside from the lemon juice tip, the other things I found helpful are: 1. chill dough, 2. place cookies far apart (they spread), and 3) bake for exactly 8 minutes.

text:
OUTSTANDING!!  I won 2nd prize in a cookie contest at work with these.  The only thing I changed a bit was add more cinnamon as I went along.  I used a teaspooful and baked ONLY 8 minutes.  I was standing at the oven door with my ovenmit ready to take them out.  Also, I used a silpat and just slid that off the hot pan and let them cool 1 min...they were chewy in the middle and crispy on the outside.  PERFECT!

text:
I had never heard of a snickerdoodle before but with all of the rave reviews I had to try this. Delicious! I didn't have any cream of tartar so I subbed vinegar (same amount). I also only had about half of the amount of all-purpose flour, so I used cake flour for the remainder. I cooked them for exactly 8 minutes and they turned out perfect. I also chilled the dough before rolling into balls to make it less messy.

text:
This was indeed a tasty cookie.  I made up the batch in no time and they came out perfectly.  I did add about 1/4 tsp (give or take) of nutmeg to the cinnamon and sugar.  Also, I didn't have shortening so I used a mixture of butter and vegetable oil.  The latter modification didn't appear to change the outcome of the cookie at all.  The recipe says it should yield about 48 cookies, but I only came up with 30 or so (I prefer a larger cookie).  Great recipe.

userID:

Display Name:
NATALIESMOM
isPro:

22

19
favoritesCount:
68
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677177.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These cookies have a very good flavor and texture.  The kids really liked them.  I used butter flavor shortening instead of plain.  The only problem I had with this recipe is that the dough was way too wet to shape into balls.  I had to add an extra 1/2 cup of flour to cut down the stickiness and put it in the refrigerator for an hour. Even then, it wasn't as firm as it should be for shaping.  I used a scoop and spoon and just kind of rolled the lumps around in the sugar/cinn. mixture that way.  Overall these are tasty cookies!
Review:
Rating:
5

userID:

Display Name:
~MOMMY~

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/39294.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've been making this same recipe since I was a child!  Cookies have a great taste, and always look nice.  Take them out of the oven while still puffy (I bake for 10 minutes for oven), and allow them to sit on the pan for a few minutes after baking.  Cookies will flatten a bit, but still look nice and stay very chewy after cooling.  I halved the amount of cinnamon simply because I don't like the darker color that the full amount gives the cookies.  I used parchment paper on my pan and had no problems with the bottoms browing too much.  If you're looking for a tasty, chewy, bakery-like Snickerdoodle recipe, feel confident in using this one!  One batch made 26 medium-sized cookies.

5

I only had 1/3 cup of shortening on hand, so I used butter to compensate for the difference. I also used 3 tbsp and 3 tsp of sugar/cinnamon respectively, but should have stuck with the amounts stated in the recipe--I had a lot left over. I followed others' advice and baked 8 min, removing to cooling rack right out of the oven. All in all, this is a very tasty cookie with a great texture.

Display Name:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have been looking for a snickerdoodle recipe ever since Mrs. Fields discontinued their giant snickerdoodle. It was the only cookie I wanted from there and I was so disappointed when they stopped making it. 

This one was EXACTLY what I was looking for! I read through some of the reviews and made some changes. I cooked them at 375 for 10 minutes, I cut out the cinnamon because I wanted just a plain sugar cookie. I used all butter because I didn't have shortening and I used lemon juice instead of cream of tartar. 

I wasn't expecting them to be exactly what I was looking for so I didn't get my hopes up but when they came out of the oven and I tasted one, I was thrilled. They were perfect! They tasted exactly as I remembered snickerdoodles - very vanilla-ey. I'm so glad I found this recipe! I haven't had a snickerdoodle for about 4-5 years now and I missed them. Now I can make them myself instead of paying 3 bucks a cookie at a place like Mrs. Fields. Thanks!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:

This is a very good, basic recipe for snickerdoodles.  They turn out just how you would expect them too.  Yummy.  Next time I'm going to try refrigerating the dough for an hour or so before rolling into balls.  Mine cooked a bit flatter than I would like and it would probably help them keep their shape better.  Very good.  Take them out after 8 minutes if you want them chewy.

text:
I am such a fiendish gal for snickerdoodles. Quite possibly my favorite cookie besides peanut butter and double chocolate. These were soft and chewy and cinnamon-perfect. I'm a huge fan of soft cookies, so I tended to keep mine on the border of undercooked. I made two batches, one that kept to the recommended cooking time for my friends and then a smaller batch for me, where it was still very soft in the center. The edges were just beginning to brown when I whisked them out. Outstanding cookies; I think I'll try the other Mrs. Sigg recipes.

text:
Wow these are good!  I've never had a snickerdoodle before but there were so many good reviews I decided to try it.  The taste reminds me of those little cinnamon and sugar donuts that you buy at the fair! I tried my first batch at 375 and it was a little underdone, however I was using a Pampered Chef baking stone and I should know better, things don't burn on those unless you really screw up!  The rest were baked at 400 for exactly 8 min and they were perfect.  It is true that the baggie trick works but it does put too much cinnamon on it, rolling would be better.  They will look undercooked but harden as they cool.  The BEST cookie recipe I've tried on here to date, thanks Mrs. Sigg!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/146454.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Quite possibly one of the best cookie recipes ever!  For the folks who have been disappointed with the cookies, be sure not to overbake - pull them out of the oven at 8 to 9 minutes tops.  I use a parchment paper-lined cookie sheet and they come out to perfection every time.  I make mine smallish and can get 6 dozen out of this recipe easy.  They are simply DIVINE!  Definitely use the 1/2 shortening and 1/2 butter combination.  I also roll about 3/4 of the balls in the cinnamon sugar to ensure you get a nice, even coating when they are finished.  Everyone will think you are a baking genius as beautiful as these babies come out!  THANK YOU, Mrs. Siggs!  :oD

country:
None
text:
Very good cookie! Reminds me of my Mom's snickerdoodles. I used a convection oven and baked at 400 degrees for exactly 8 minutes. Came out perfect! Chewy on inside, slightly crisp on edges.  The dough was very easy to work with and I was able to mix the batter within just a few minutes. I mixed the wet ingredients with a hand mixer and then incorporated the dry ingredients by hand, careful not to overmix. The dough was soft, but not sticky and formed balls very easily. My kids and their friends LOVED them. Will definately make these again.

This recipe (almost all snickerdoodle recipes are just about identical) was really no different - in ingredients or taste.  The ONLY way I improved upon it and got rave reviews was to use MAKAR cinnamon from Cinnabon company.  There was a noticeable difference in taste - plus I used EQUAL amnts of cinnamon and sugar to coat the cookies.  Delicious!!

text:
Make sure you have enough ingred. on hand to double the recipe because you are going to need to make a double batch of these!  I don't know how others got away with storing these for a week, because mine barely lasted the afternoon and I had to make more.  As far as baking them, I got 36 cookies exactly.  Mine baked for exactly 8 minutes, then I moved them to waxed paper on the counter.  Did not think a cooling rack would have worked with these.  I figured they'd fall through the cracks in the rack.  Worked very well.  Very nice shaped cookies.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent recipe! The cookies are crispy on the outside & chewy on the inside. I used butter flavored Crisco and real butter. I baked them for only 8 mins. on parchment. I left them on the baking sheet for a couple of minutes and then transferred them onto a wire cooling rack. I agree with a previous reviewer that cinnamon/sugar mixture should be increased to 3T white sugar, and 3tsp. cinnamon. I took the advice of another reviewer and placed the mixture in a sandwich baggie and dropped one ball in at a time to coat.

None
text:
Make sure that you don't overcook them. For high altitude (Denver), I just added 1/4 cup more flour. Worked just fine. The first batch I cooked too long and they were hard by the evening. The second batch I made sure to undercook, and they were perfect. Put in a tupperware and seal, and they stay soft for about a week.

text:
I have to add my praises to all of the rest. These cookies took me straight back to childhood. I hadn't tasted one since I was barely tall enough to reach the cookie jar, but I never forgot that distinctive taste. These were indeed perfect. Parchment paper on the baking sheet was a great suggestion, as it made for easy and speedy removal.          Storing these in an air-tight container didn't work for us, as it made the texture too gummy. Wrapping them in foil worked perfectly. I will try these again soon, and would love to try brown sugar for rolling the dough as suggested by another reviewer.

text:
As if this needed my rating, but I did want to tell you what I did differently.  I scaled this back to 24, just to try it before the cookie exchange.  Then I used all butter (in place of shortening) and used self rising flower and omitted baking soda, salt and cream of tarter.  I cooked a little longer only becuase they didn't seem to "set" so I cooked about 14-16 minutes.  They were crunchy but WONDERFUL.  For the cookie exchange, I will probably stick to the 8-10 minutes.  Thank for this creat recipe.

text:
I have made these Snickerdoodles several times now and we love them!  My husband was very surprised because he has never been a Snickerdoodle fan before.  The only change I make to the recipe is that I change the topping measurements to 3 tbsp sugar and 3 tsp cinnamon rather than 2 tbsp sugar/2 tsp cinnamon because the first time I made them I ran out of the topping before I ran out of dough.  Anyway, this is one of our new favorite recipes!

text:
Absolutly the best cookie I've ever made! Snickerdoodles are my favorite but mine (out of the Better Homes and Garden cookbook) never seemed to turn out as well as other peoples that I had tasted. So I compaired the recipes. I had been using more flour and less cr of tartar and baking soda,per my recipe, hence my cookies weren't rising and crackeling like they were supposed to. This will be my Snickerdoodle recipe from now on. Perfect as written!

text:
Maybe it's just me.  I thought I liked snickerdoodles (been awhile), but this cookie tasted bland and boring.  Even my husband (he'll eat any cookie) thought they were kind of boring.  I agree with other reviewers soft out of the oven, but hard within a short time.  I probably could have cooked them for only 7 minutes.  I would err on the side of underdone when taking them out of the oven.  They harden up quickly after cooling!! Be careful.  Either way I won't make them again, but I'm sure they are a good cookie.  Just not my thing.

text:
I have made these snickerdoodles many times and they always turn out wonderful. 8 minutes baking time is perfect. I cool the dough in the refrigerator between batches, so it's easier to roll. I just made these for my daughter to take to school for her birthday, but I modified it a bit. We rolled them in sprinkles (the tiny round multi-colored ones) then baked them. My daughter had fun rolling them in the sprinkles, and they turned out so cute and very yummy! I got lots of compliments on them. Next time I make them with the sprinkles I might only put them on the top...it was pretty sweet. I like this recipe because the cookies don't flatten out. They always turn out moist and chewy. Great recipe!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have only had snickerdoodles once before - and they may have been over cooked because there were not as nice as these.

My tip - if you have the choice of one or the other - UNDERBAKE them...  I cooked them for about 6 minutes and when you pushed them they were still quite soft but as they cooled they got crispy round the edges.  Trust me - do a small batch to test it if you like - but the shorter time is better :)

I also found that (on my second batch) they were nice if you rolled them in ground cloves, nutmeg and cinnamon because it brings out the flavour more.

But all in all - a great recipe!
Review:

2

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/54.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The first batch I baked for exactly 8 minutes and they came out pretty burnt on the bottom, the second batch for exactly 7.5 minutes and they too came out a little burnt on the bottom but tasted very good about 10 minutes after coming out of the oven. But about an hour or so later, they tasted even more burnt and were dry. Nobody really ate these and many got thrown away. These cookies could be really very good if you're just very cafeful with the bake time. Also, these cookies don't flatten out (which threw me off). I'd say about 6.5-7 minutes bake time.

text:
These came out dry, cake-like, and rather bland.  Part of the reason is that they didn't spread at all, so I left them in the oven longer than I should have, thinking they needed more time.  If I make these again, I will use all butter in place of the shortening so that they will spread more.  I'll add a bit more sugar too.  They weren't bad, just not what I was wanting.  My husband said they were more like muffins, which was pretty accurate.

text:
Great, classic snickerdoodles, but a couple of minor things... I used a full cup of butter shortning plus 3 T of water instead of half butter and half shortning. Also, I had to add almost a cup of flour to thicken it up a bit. I also found that it got easier to mold into balls after it had sat out for a while to set. But, 10 minutes in the oven made for perfect, wonderful cookies, just like I remember from my childhood...

This recipe has all the ingredients to be a good cookie (minus the crisco) and it is...I found trying to figure out when they are done without burning them is a bit frustrating. One too done ...one set googy...third perfect..... 8-8.5 minutes at 400 using parchment paper seems to do the trick with my oven.  I also added currants to the third rack of cookies and they were liked best. I followed the recipe exactly even though I wanted to use all butter....might the next time...I appreciate all comments given as I read them all before making any of the recipes on the site.....Very helpful.....Keep them coming :O)

I've always loved making snickerdoodles. When I ran across this recipe that varied slightly from my own I thought I'd give it a try.  I'm glad I did!  These cookies stayed moist and chewy and perfect.  I like rolling them in the cinnamon sugar but for a change I used orange flavoring instead of vanilla and frosted them with orange butter frosting instead of sugaring them.  They didn't even last the whole day at my house! Now I'm thinking of all the variations that I could with this cookie recipe. Thanks, Beth for a great recipe.

text:
My wife & I really, really like this recipe.  The first time we made them, we also made some oatmeal-chocolate chip cookies, because these sounded a little plain & boring.  Although tasty, the chocolate chip cookies went stale & we wound up making another batch of these they were soooo good.  I did not have any problem with the cooking time or temperature as some of the others did, but I didn't get quite as many cookies out of the batch as the recipe said I would.  Also, try experimenting with the cinnamon mixture -- I added a pinch of ginger & fresh nutmeg.

text:
This recipe is wonderful.  I found that 9 1/2 mins was sufficient enough to set them without burning them or having them turn out too soft.  just right.  I also added a little touch of my own to my batch.  I pressed my thumb in the middle of the rolled cookie to make a small indentation and added a seedless raspberry jam in the center.  Mmmm.  Is it ever good.  But give it a good 10 mins to cool before eating because THEY'RE HOT!  Ouch!

text:
These do taste good, but I had the burning problem.  The first batch was wonderful (my oven must not had been at 400 yet), the second batch started to burn at 8 minutes.  I lowered the time by one minute and removed them from the baking sheet right away and was able to save the rest of the cookies!  I will make them again, I'll just keep my adjustments since ovens DO VARY!  :)  Thank you Mrs. Siggs.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Fantastic tasting cookie.  Very chewy and melts in your mouth.  I love how the cookie is even chewy next day, which makes them disappear fast around my house.  I took a double-sized batch into work, and they were all gone before lunchtime. 

Two suggestions: Grease a small ice cream scooper and use that for even-sized cookies.  I had problems with smaller ones getting too dark before the larger cookies were done.  Also if you use dark nonstick pans, make sure to use parchment paper or the bottoms burn.

text:
This recipe is VERY simple to make, great for kids. Cookies are really tasty, especially if you're looking for something that is not really sugary. One thing I found is baking at 400 degrees for 8 minutes resulted in burned cookies. I lowered it to 350 and baked them for 5-6 mins, worked perfectly! *Also used no cream of tartar, were delicious.

text:
Because my friends and families love "big handfuls" I made these cookies larger than the recipe called for.  The flavor was great and they kept well. I didn't experience the problem of some reviewers who complained that they turned into hard hockey pucks.  I would recommend that you don't overbake and store in a tightly covered container.

These were very tasty cookies, with the exception that the texture really changes after they cool off.  My children loved them, but I was looking for something that wouldn't turn into a hockey puck, and this cookie DIDN'T deliver.  I you have guests that will be eating them right out of the oven then you are safe, but I wouldn't take them to work, etc, because as I said the texture really turns stale and hard after an hour or so.
